wKg5dT7VxRv3dpA1fAOMRQ.text: We celebrated a birthday at Best Friend recently and loved our experience there! Our server was extremely knowledgeable and tailored recommendations to our group. I thought the decor was great, very Instagram-able. Be aware that it is definitely a "lively" environment. The food was top tier; I especially enjoyed the kimchi fried rice, the spicy pork BBQ, and the eggplant schnitzel.  A lot of spice, a lot of flavor! I felt the menu was very reasonably priced considering it's location and the quality of our experience. Already planning to return!

XMW5k6D2ywRzqdZqBVb_cw.text: First off, decor, service and music are on point. The Kogi tacos and carrots are great. The a-frame ribs and slipper shrimp were okay. Dessert was delicious.

TAftgiXfwW5maddcUtsfZQ.text: Last Sunday While staying at MGM Park decided to try out Bestfriend.Food was good but customer service was horrible, from the girl who is standing there hosting to the bartender being rude and not making me the correct drink. Wound have given 5 stars if customer service would have been up to par. Your no longer a food truck your in a casino that has return customers not just tourist. Roy you need to teach the restaurant staff customer service skills.

INzL3y2xZQpBevoAk6wYOg.text: everything way too salty include salad ,it seems like they had salt for free, worst rchief ever, do you know over burn food cost cancer.

photos.caption: Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States

EbDIZbHewg-tMiblriqQ5A.text: Service could have been a lot better, server forgot to input my wife's cocktail, which is fine, we understand mistakes happen, but server lied and said she forgot to pick it up from bar, when clearly was not True because she didn't go get it from bar, instead she helped other tables until the drink was MADE and a runner brought it...long story short, don't lie. Also if an entree is not brought out with the other person's meal, please let them know the status, like sorry the other entree is coming right up or it may take a few extra minutes, no problem. We waited for awhile until second entree came out. Food was great! The highlight was meeting the owner :) The place was nicely decorated and had the LA vibe and style to it including the music, overall, we would go back just not go out of our way to go back.

t9MzE4zMBYcwt4C2G9tqWw.text: I rarely give a restaurant 5 stars since I always believe that everyone needs room for improvement.  However, this restaurant exceed my expectation.  So, it was a long day for our family and we got to the hotel around 9:00pm.  We were hungry, tired and cold.  We decided to stay in our hotel and find something to eat inside to avoid the cold weather and of course the walk.  We wanted to try the restaurant so we called ahead to see if it's still opens.  They told us that the restaurant is closed as all tables were reserved ahead of time.  Disappointedly, we came down stair planning to eat at La La Noodle.  Then we decided to take a chance and came in to Best Friend to ask for a table.  It was almost 10:00pm.  The hostess told us that the dining room is full and we can sit at the bar for dinner, so of course yes lol ...  the bar only had 2 seaters left but the server at the bar was nice enough to get us extra chair to fit 3 people at the bar.  Services were excellent, servers were friendly, sweet, and very attentive.  When the food took long time to come out (we did not care as we enjoyed talking and enjoying the vibe from the restaurant), she apologized repeatedly and offered us some stickers to choose from.  The vibes were awesome for me, Asian hip hop with a little funk and a little punk to it.  Here is about the food:  - Pork belly Chagu bowl:  it was a flavor explosion in my mouth.  I put one big scoop in my mouth and everything works; warm rice, saltiness of the pork belly, citrus from the pickled radish and brocolini, sweetness from the green salsa and cheese, spiciness from the red salsa.  Wow ... it is comfort food for me.  It could cure any hangover lol   - Spicy cold noodle (hubby dish - vegetarian):  different from classic Korean cold noodle.  When I had a bite, it was overly citrus for me.  It was sour that makes me puckered.  As you all know, I am weak with citrus lol.  I think it needs some salt and more fresh vegetables or herbs like cucumbers to balance out the citrus.  - Spicy pork BBQ (brother-in-law dish):  classic Korean dish and taste.  Nothing I have not had at Authentic Korean restaurant in the past.  Rice was extra for the dish.    - Banchan was not free (bummer).  I love banchan with Korean food.  If they make banchan free then it would have been even better.  Overall, I would not hesitate to come back to this restaurant when I am in town.  Definitely will try to make reservation to be in the dining room next time :)

photos.caption: Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States

Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States

5wBFhxuLzSi-IOulXsjolQ.text: Chef Roy Choi brought the LA food scene to Vegas. A mix of street and asian comfort food at its finest. A place with many choices! Loved the Hibiscus soju slushee, carnitas tacos, and the Tamarind stew with Black Cod

Y3yNIgIwbc6-Pw1MBrdSlw.text: What a fun and awesome restaurant. The atmosphere transcends you to another place.  This was such a great spot and I can't wait to come back.  I had the short rib tacos and the pork belly bowl.  Both were excellent!  I recommend Best Friend to anyone looking for an authentic dining experience in a casual atmosphere.

Ih7ihFVeYtr7LcNGry70xA.text: I've lived in Vegas for almost 7 years now and have eaten at a lot of the places on the strip. This by far is the best food I have ever had! I was blown away and only had their late night menu! Can't wait to come back for the full menu. Mind blown from how flavorful and unique every dish was.  Highly recommend the Kalbi, any of the tacos and fries!!!   PS I also rarely yelp anything so the fact that I'm taking the time to do this really shows just how amazing Best Friend is!

zYcDKc4bfjG6PF8xe1gmmw.text: Never heard of it in LA until I came to Vegas.  Really simple review.... if you die without having these taco's you have missed out on life... seriously

B-eXK1rVRXBicid3-ST4Wg.text: This place is absolutely hyped up. The service and the atmosphere are great but the food is very bad. I understand the concept is Asian fusion but the dishes I tried were overwhelmed with sauces and oil. I had popcorn shrimp, unit fried rice and bbq short ribs. The short ribs will be my pick but it was super overpriced. Dessert was the mango pudding. This is a must try, it was a bit too sweet for my taste but overall this is the one I'm impressed the most. Best friend was a cool experience but I will not come back. I would rather go to Eataly next door

xct5yDgnOnLIZoIzVljJCQ.text: Bomb dot com.  I could live in the spicy pork.   Cool spot with a great vibe.  Don't let the front disguise you.   Everything we had was delicious.  Will be back for sure next time in Vegas.

XC0vUfdDUZxt-wq62IDnVg.text: Hmmmm,  what to say?  I had high hopes for a better than average casino meal here, nope, not gonna happen.  Great ambiance, good service were the best part. I ordered the spare rib tacos and the kimchi fried rice. The tacos were mission adequate, but nothing that isn't being served anyplace else in this town. The kimchi fried rice was abysmal,  just a soggy heap of rice with absolutely nothing in it that tastes like kimchi or even remotely flavorful.  If I were blindfolded and going on taste alone I would have guessed I was at a TGI FRIDAYS or some other Sysco supplied dump. Blech. Roy, please pack your knives and go.

fwtxupxo7cvacq5O49uyqA.text: Loud. Obnoxious. Track suits. Awesome. Spicy pork Bbq and short rib tacos were my favorite but everything was magical. Thank you chef!

wdHcbIrJRw3yhtC5e9y4kQ.text: Best Friend is classic Roy Choi. Heavy, warm, spicy, toasted, flavorful and gooey goodness. Bologna sandwich was heavy (good thing) and very reminiscent of childhood grilled bologna sandwiches. Wings had a definite Asian tang to them. Kogi mixed with traditional Korean dishes mixed with Las Vegas style fine dining such as steak and lobster. Food styles for all ages and personalities. Great ambience. A Roy Choi world is a world I want to live in. #KogiPorVida

-BiJJ7mJ1VgZ-TADow76nQ.text: Ambience took me back to LA!  Waiters in the BF track suits, 90-00 underground hip hop on the speakers, old school Asian glamour shots in the menus (including a shot of the Beat Junkies) and the Kogi Short Rib Tacos reminiscent from the Kogi trucks that breeded the tacos 10 years ago.  Negatives - overpriced and the night we attended (new year's day) they didn't serve the Chego Pork Belly or the Uni Dynamite dishes.  How can you not have some menu items on New Years Day?!?! We were disappointed considering those were well recommended, plus my mother-in-law wanted to order it.  So she was already disappointed.  They also charge $3 for a small bowl of white rice, and banchan is $4 each.  Majority of dishes are a la carte and portions aren't large.  Don't get me wrong, the Kalbi short ribs and Kogi Tacos were good, but while I was eating and thinking of how much I was spending, I also was thinking I could just do a run to Greenland Korean Market and cook myself up similar tasting Kalbi ribs for a quarter of the price.  We ordered the Octopus and my father-in-law said there were too many veggies, not enough octopus.  Soondubu was good and filling and had similar flavor and spiciness as the Octopus.  I do love Roy bringing the old school LA scene, music and food tradition into Vegas though.  I want to give the resto another shot hoping the pork belly is in stock next time.

xsBu3UpOpLYcQ_CquEj8GQ.text: A nice place to have food and drinks. The only complain I've got is the selection of drinks

7NURL2iZLu57tOJFmHLp4w.text: The vibe of this place is amazing !  Old school hip hop vibe , great music, great uniforms .    When it comes to our server, she was really nice, but rarely checked on us. When it came to ordering , this is where it was odd. We came on nye at around 745 pm, this place opened maybe couple weeks before . My menu had a cheaper price on something I ordered and told the lady, she said we got the wrong menus and they must have forgot to change over the menu. Wow , couple of weeks and prices are already going up or prices went up for NYE!   Food was not hot , maybe sitting under a heating lamp? I thought it was made to order(hence the long wait for some things ) . Flavors were just okay for the price.   If you want something with a cool awesome vibe and okay overpriced food, this is the place .

aKMzP7rj_P2frO4Ixvl80A.text: Amazing food! Roy Choi is perfect for some good grub, great music, cool vibe, and you don't have to be dressed prim and proper. Best of all the entire staff is very welcoming and knowledgeable. From management, to servers, to bartenders, etc. Everyone knows how to offer great hospitality. And the drinks are AWESOME! I would 100% recommend this place to anyone.

QiIDyPMS-xgZ8Gt0ZY9rjA.text: Delicious. The shrimp and short rib tacos were so good. The spicy pork bbq was even better! Big portions that are perfect for sharing. Can't wait to go back!

GM0sUGBlnQPLNu9OQmPqpA.text: This experience was not such a good one. Stick to the menu for cocktails. The food was mediocre for the price. $85 TaFood Truck. The worst part was I walked away with bug bites all over my arm. Will NEVER go back!

zseCd97ONVR1pPyTTsssLg.text: Excellent in all categories! I'm a big Roy Choi fan as all of his LA joints are fantastic, and Best Friend is another killer spot. Fun, party atmosphere, great music and ofcourse amazing food.   Trust all the food, if it's on the menu it's amazing. Highlights-  Elote  All the Banchan Wings Soondubu soup Garlic Chickeb Galbi! Short rib Tacos Kimchi Fried Rice Dumplings Hawaiian buns  Can't wait to come back!

zjGsSRG63JdlacaxBkb6XA.text: Fun new place on the Las Vegas Strip. All the staff are wearing track suits and the whole place is an eccentric collection of 80s, 90s nostalgia -- convenience store entrance and golden age hip hop. The menu is also a comprehensive collection of Choi's popular LA restaurants Kogi, Pot, Commissary, and A-Frame. Our meal started with a fluffy Hawaiian bun, which was perfect. We had some kimchi banchan also. The kimchi fried rice was excellent, but it was served in an enamel cast iron dutch oven which made me overly careful to not scratch. We tried the OG ribs, but this one was too dried out. The dumplings were also flavorful and had a silky thin skin. In the end, we had the bingsu topped with yummy foam and condensed milk, which at the time was dragonfruit flavored. It had white dragonfruit pieces and the sorbetto was a pink dragonfruit. Roy Choi was also around.

_1Ra6pDupGfpPzrn1eb93w.text: I had an excellent dinner here with my boyfriend while we were in town and was blown away by the entire experience. We came on a Friday night without a reservation and luckily got seated right away. All the staff were friendly and the main dining room was a lot of fun; it included a DJ spinning 90's hip hop & R&B. I ordered the watermelon tequila cocktail and it was to die for; super refreshing and actually had a good amount of alcohol. For food, we ordered the Kimchi Fried Rice, Chilli Pasta, Dumplings, and tacos. Every dish was great and flavorful! I really wish I could've fit more in my belly because the KBBQ looked so good at the tables next to us. Everything from the decor to the menu to the DJ was really well thought out and a sweet love letter to Los Angeles (my hometown). Can't wait to come back and try more things off the menu.

NKD4tOJ78X1WA362rH6I5w.text: If I can, I would give this place 10 stars, from the service, music, decoration and concept. But what top it all off is the FOOD. We chose the Testing menu curated by the chef himself. Everything taste great and the portions were big. The food continuously came out non-stop. We got lucky that Roy Choi was in the restaurant and got a picture with him. Such a cool person. Our servers, Scott and Christina, were both entertaining and courteous. They did a great job! Attached is our picture with him and dessert. Sorry no good pictures of the testing menu because we devoured everything before we could take a good picture.

poqX3FcXHwB5N8qlMAZMSg.text: The price is a little pricey compared to this type of dining off the strip but you're paying for the ambiance and service.   Their small plate options make it easy to try a variety off the menu but the plates are quite small. Think before you order and look at the pictures online for reference.   We enjoyed our drinks and the friendly service. I'd bring back tourists but not necessarily the locals.

obj_FK05wrMIE3roMWMZ5w.text: One of the best eating experiences I've ever had.   When you arrive, the front bar is made to look like the inside of a corner liquor store and it's a really cool vibe. Very causal and relaxed with a few high tables and some seats at the bar.   Then, as you get taken to your seats, it's like you go through two sets of doors that lead you to a completely different world. Modern, sophisticated but at the same time down to Earth and not pretentious in the least. There was a live DJ playing great music and I'm pretty sure this is the first time I've ever danced in my seat all of the way through dinner.   But enough with the ambiance, let's get to the food.   We ordered four of the banchan (Cucumbers, kimchi, broccolini and daikon), elote and BBQ kalbi (short ribs).   As you can tell, it's a bit of an odd combination, Korean and Mexican but that's part of what's so fun about Best Friend, the menu is kinda all over the place but in an amazing way.   The banchan were all very good and the elote and BBQ kalbi were flat out amazing!   All in al, Best Friend was one of the biggest highlights of our weekend in Vegas.

yd0zBTtgA_SFQKxGqqswyQ.text: The Roy Choi reverse speakeasy is fucking awesome! I have loved Roy Choi's food at Chego and the Kogi food trucks in LA and this is like a greatest hits of his food but with a cool bar and hidden restaurant. It is a bucket list type stop that makes Korean BBQ mainstream for the masses except the banchan isn't free. Can't miss the Chego Bowl, Kalbi Tacos and Kalbi BBQ

nO5WBi-uOj4q6rf0CJ7Vpw.text: Ah - I finally got to try Roy Choi's new Vegas stop and sure enough, it feels like a 'best hits' of his LA restaurants as well as some fun ideas that fits the Vegas mold.   Best Friend can be found near the 'middle' of Park MGM (if you come in through Eataly from the street-side, it's to your right just as you hit the casino floor / if you come in through the lobby, head towards Eataly, it'll be towards your left side). The decor is the first big thing that you'll notice. There's two sections - the first being a really bombastic, old-school and bright bar filled with different merchandise. Go through the construction-like hangings though to the other side and you get a much more chic and stylish restaurant that had a DJ the Thursday I stopped by and some beautiful artwork all-around that is much more dimly lit. I sat at the bar - I had a RSVP but the restaurants was about 75% full when I arrived.   Food and cocktails-wise I tried: +Hawaiian Bread: You get a free Hawaiian bread as you sit down. Not bad - love that someone comes around with a pan and plops it down in front of you.  +Uni Bowl: The uni bowl is smaller than you think it will be but is super, super rich. Some will think it's a bit salty but the dish I think is delicious. You get a few pieces of uni and a lot of the coverings that you see on a speciality oyster dish. It's super fascinating and worth a try if you're a fan of these types of dishes.  +The Seasonal Veggies: An okay helping of random veggies. I think I would get one of the banchans instead next time but if you have a group and are looking for some greens, it's not a bad mixture. Just pretty straightforward.  +The Arugula Cocktail: I wasn't sure what to make of this but the cocktail in the end was a good mix. Fresh and tangy.   Kudos to the bartender - he was not only super friendly (free shots to those at the bar when we were there - some midori mixture) but also was cutting corn and super good on his explanations.   Prices are high which is typical for being on the Vegas strip but still disappointing to see when you're given smaller portions. No big complaints though overall!

fXHo4LF-c14CobuCnFVypQ.text: We had reservations for 2 on a Friday night and it was about a month since the grand opening. We were staying at Park MGM this time so it was very convenient to simply get ready for dinner and make our way down to the casino level to eat.  First impression is one of sensory overload. From the liquor store feel of the front bar area to the LA poster wall to the hundreds of stickers on the counters to the alcoholic slushies (jameson & ginger, hennesey & cola, etc.)... it was all so crazy. So you gotta know that what looks to be the area of the liquor store cash register is where you check in for dinner. If your table isnt quite ready yet, they will politely ask you to wait or have a drink at the bar and they will come get you. We waited about 5 minutes before we were brought in to the main dining area. You go through 2 sets of heavyweight plastic curtains like a meat locker has. Then boom... The dining area is totally different. If you've been to any of Roy Choi's restaurants in the past then you will see some similar design cues. The suspended plants and greenery reminded me a bit of the Commissary and the clean and modern aesthetic of the dining tables reminded me of Pot and the lobby of the Line hotel.   Did I mention there is a DJ? He played such good music throughout the night. Everything from classic hip hop to R&B to MoTown classics. I really loved the vibe. I also loved the photos of Los Angeles that are on either ends of the dining hall. I know some of those photos were done by Travis Jensen so it was great to see them up close and displayed inside Best Friend... The photos that accompanied the menu were something else. It was great to see flashback photos like that. If you're from LA or anywhere in Cali, you will get it. It was cool to see old photos of the Beat Junkies and K-Town folks. It was crazy to see a photo of some gangsters from back in the day that we knew. Wasnt expecting that one... Haha.  We started off with some banchan. We went with the daikon and the cucumber. ($4 each). I liked the daikon but it was a little spicy for me. I love daikon but I just couldnt eat too much of it. The cucumbers were great. They had a spiciness to them as well but the sesame flavor added to them made it so tasty. Really good. I would get it again for sure. The complimentary warm Hawaiian bread rolls were great and a nice beginner to the meal.   We next got the pork and beef dumplings ($12). These were really good. They also come with ginger and tofu and a spicy dipping sauce. Very tasty and I recommend it. Next we got the Chego pork belly bowl ($18). I was glad they had this because I have yet to dine at Chego. This dish also comes with fried egg, broccoli, radish, cotija and peanuts. This was a good sized bowl, perfect for 2-3 people. The pork belly was tender. The fried egg and rice were perfect together. It also comes with a spicy sauce that the pork belly is slathered in. It was a little spicy for me after a while. I dont eat very spicy so the menu challenged that a little bit but I was game. I ate all that I could for sure... The last dish we had was the Kogi short rib tacos ($12). The world famous. This takes me back to the Alibi Room and Undefeated/Stussy parties where the Kogi trucks would  post up and feed us along La Brea Ave. Classic times... The tacos came with healthy portion of korean bbq, a chili-soy slaw, red salsa and cilantro, onion and lime to squeeze. These tacos were delicious and better than I even remember. You have to get them if you have never had them before.  Service was great. Our server was a riot... They are all dressed in Adidas track suits and the bussers wear shorts, high socks and crusher hats. We really enjoyed our dinner at Best Friend. To those people that dont get it or question the design and execution of the place, just let Chef Roy Choi take you on a tour of the senses... a tour through Koreatown Los Angeles through his eyes... Thanks Chef! And we appreciated you coming around to say hello and shake hands with all the diners that night. We'll be back again for sure...

qOKUnbTKmnUiaX6-QNBGPw.text: Stopped here on a whim before the Cher concert and OMG, we were pleasantly surprised! The place is unique and quirky, even the entrance (you gotta go thru a store looking place to get to the restaurant). Love the decor and the throwback 1980s hip-hop uniforms. Walking in, the smell of the food is amazing! Our waiter was Corey and he was cool, but his sidekick, "Hot Scott", was super awesome. He recommended all sorts of food, had good conversation, and kept us laughing. He has a way of making you feel like you're a special table, even though I'm sure he makes everyone feel that way.. haha. We weren't that hungry, so we tried the kogi short rib tacos and the garlic chicken. The tacos were on the spicy side, so I wouldn't order them again, but if you're a fan of spice, you'll love these! However, the flavor and the tenderness of the garlic chicken was super good. I'll definitely go back for those and to try some other stuff!

av1_Vy3qXUmmWULRs3LZGQ.text: Here we go: The What: Korean/Mex Fusion Food. PreFix for us. Kimchi/Salad Plate, Spicy Tempura Shrimp, Tacos, Chicken w/ Left Over Taco Sauce!! The Who: Roy MuthaFkn Choi mastermind menu. Wonderful waitresses, very knowledgeable of food and drinks.  The Where: Amazing installation! Pop Up Style Feel, almost felt like a supper club vibe. Great reception/bar area. Soundtrack and ambience was A1 Star of the show: Desert of course and Spicy Shrimp!

zR5N7g13DG1OQ_8OsJ7YFA.text: Worst services, ok food. I used to recommend this place to my customers at work but no more.  Very rude hosts, a server and a bartender. Just stuck up attitudes. Food was soooooo late and cold.  Manager was nice, she took off one food from my bill because it took way too long time to come to my table and when it got to my table the the food was soggy and not hot. Also most of the food we ordered was too spicy. It doesn't indicate anywhere in the menus that it was that spicy. Will not recommend this place to anybody and will never go back again.

e7TFfg0wsOkVGMgt12Je2A.text: I saw the buzz of this place during the soft opening by LA's Roy Choi who looks like Jackie Chan. Walked in and straight away not a fan. I wouldn't take a date here and wouldn't post up here either. I get the concept scheme but it's not my kind of place. None of it makes sense and maybe it's not suppose to. I don't fit the clientele here. Maybe they were going for a themed establishment to lure customers. I tried to give it a chance but still walked out feeling eew. Yelp says Hot & New but I left feeling hot & eew.       The feel is like walking into an East Coast Bodega in a dodgy neighborhood but with very poor lighting. On the West Coast I'd compare it to walking into an off brand liquor store that has random items like Ramen and candy on the shelves. The table tops are plastered with sticker graffiti. It feels like they cleared some shelves and put chairs to sit in. It also feels like hanging out inside of an ice cream truck. This is the entrance bar area.       No one comes to help you, if you didn't know that the restaurant was thru the plastic curtain that looks like a walk in fridge you wouldn't know it's back there. No one comes to help you or tell you how anything works. So if you walk in you'll only see the bar entrance area not the restaurant in the back. Workers wear track suits so you walk right past them trying to find someone who works there or where to check in at. Again made no sense to me.        The menu is Korean Mexican which I don't get either. It was packed with people watching a big game. Loud drunks blurting profanities and yelling at the football players like the players can hear while kids, children sat a few feet away. That wasn't cool either. If this is your scene here's a new place on the strip. Totally not my kind of place and a bad experience on the strip.  Mel M  Yelp 19:2

Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shelves from a dim lit bodega /off brand liquor store is the vibe here

Pqn-sZlB6q04G8uxA-mZsg.text: I have a ton of respect for Roy Choi and what he's done as a Korean-American chef in LA, so naturally I was super excited to try his new restaurant during a trip to Vegas. Very quirky and interesting concept, which is very clear from the moment you walk in.  We had a group of 4, and we had a few dishes in mind for what we wanted to order but wanted some guidance on the amount of food that would be ideal for the size of our party. We told our server what dishes we were thinking, and she suggested taking 1 item off so we did. She then recommended a starter that we hadn't picked, which would've been perfectly fine, but she was aggressively adamant that we would love it and wrote it down as part of our order without telling us. Rude. She only took it off after my friend explicitly told her that we didn't want to order it. Making recommendations is one thing. Pressuring us to pay for something we're not interested in is another. Annoying.  In a little while, we started getting what we ordered:  - Uni Dynamite Rice: So close to being amazing, but there was an unexpectedly large amount of sriracha mayo which I found a little unnecessary and made it a little heavy. Make that uni shine, it doesn't need mayo! The menu says sriracha in the description but doesn't say "mayo" or even "aioli" anywhere, so we were a little thrown off by this.   - Chego Pork Belly Bowl: This was pretty good. Probably the best dish of the night.  - Kalbi: Not bad, not great. A little chewy.  - Complimentary warm Hawaiian buns: Really enjoyed this!   - Itaewon: This was clearly a play on budae jjigae and by far the largest part of our meal, but we were so disappointed to taste that it was SO OVERWHELMINGLY SALTY. You could see that it was reduced down HEAVILY, to the point where it wasn't a stew anymore - It was thick almost like the texture of a heavy clam chowder. Even with the salt factor aside, it also...did not look or taste like budae jjigae. It tasted more like the seasoning you'd use for maeuntang (Koreans, you know what I'm talking about - They are not the same).   We ended up feeling super full at the end of our meal, largely because the Itaewon was so salty and we had to eat it with much more rice in an attempt to dilute the flavor.   When our server came by and asked us if we were done, we told her that we were full, and then she proceeded to say, "I told you, I was right about not ordering another thing!" We laughed it off, but she came by another TWO TIMES to repeatedly tell us "I told you so" and to remind us again that we were wrong to consider ordering more food. Seriously?!  Overall, we all thought that the food ended up just being okay and the service was straight up annoying. I can't imagine that this is what Chef Roy Choi envisioned. There are endless amazing options in Vegas, both on the strip and off, so I don't think I'd go back.

CcT2B42CiPmFcCGjOaIVCw.text: It's more a 3.8, but I'll round up. We went with the menu that was $50 pp as it was recommended by the server. The dishes that were brought out were short rib tacos,  banchan, slippery shrimp, garlic chicken, Korean style pork, and date cake. Honestly, the only dish that really stood out were the short rib tacos. Everything else was good, but nothing I can't get in a regular Korean or Chinese restaurant closer to me. Great for tourists who don't want to go to Chinatown for this kind of food. If there's a next time, I'll definitely avoid that set menu and order something more unique.

-nX2Kflyj7gOYe-eApO3GQ.text: Mostly viewing "fusion" as an inauthentic means to please a wider variety of customers it was with interest but skepticism that Best Friend was approached on Saturday, Roy Choi's first foray into Las Vegas a long way from the Kogi Trucks that made him famous but the space at Park MGM somehow pulling off the combination of Bodega, Restaurant and Bar with polish and poise.      Located proximate to the former home of Andre's, recently-opened Eataly looming large next door, it is passing by neon that reads "Roy Choy Is My Best Friend" that diners will find themselves surrounded by merchandise both for show and for purchase, the hostess stand easily missed next to translucent red curtains dividing Bar from Dining Room where Hip Hop plays at modest volume.  Keeping Television at the Bar, the flowing interior instead focused on murals and illuminated street scenes beneath hanging plants, it was in a booth on the left half that two guests were seated with menus presented, the server dressed in Adidas cool but helpful in a manner that works far more effectively than the typical nonchalance of many casual Restaurants opened in the past decade.  Dubbed as a "Korean BBQ" joint based on Chef Choy's history, though there are graciously no signs of DIY grills aside from those manned by cooks in the spotless kitchen, it was after lengthy perusal of Drinks and menu sections such as "Bowls," "Pots," and "L.A. Sh*t" that decisions were made, two small servings of Banchan whetting palates alongside complimentary warm Hawaiian Rolls that are enjoyable on their own but better saved for later when they prove useful for sopping up Sauces.  Opting for one Cocktail, the savory Tequila base with fresh Watermelon and a salted rim right up the lady's alley, it was alongside a colorful Salad that Uni Dynamite Rice was handed over, the former using salt and spice to blend Radish, Chicories and Onion while whole Tongues of Sea Urchin rested atop the later imbuing Grains both fully cooked and a bit crisp with umami.  Going full-fusion for the next two, Roy's Tacos that built an empire seeing a price hike but otherwise delicious with plenty of Marinated Beef that marries well to Salsa and julienne Cabbage, it is hidden directly above these under "L.A. Sh*t" that guests will find Slippery Shrimp, the idea of Walnut Prawns, Shrimp Mayo or whatever it is called spun on its ear by all the same textures but fire where sweetness is expected.  Returning to tradition for Pots and Entrees, a Half-Rack of Lamb for $44 not incongruent with other Casino Restaurants and here prepared magnificently rare along with Baby Bok Choy plus complex Chimichurri bright with Cumin and Cilantro, those looking for value would be well-advised to invest similar dollars in a cauldron of Cod, the sharpness of Tamarind countered by Noodles, Herbs and what might by Honey in a portion that could easily be shared by three or four.  Turning sweets over to Park MGM Executive Pastry Chef Angibeau Philippe, his calendar undoubtedly crowded by such a rapidly evolving property, it is nonetheless with French precision that each Dessert is plated, the "Sundae for Two" largely for show but not skimping on complexity while the $10 Date Cake and Mango Budino are both showstoppers, the former giving Gordon Ramsay's Sticky Toffee Pudding a serious run for its money while the Pudding matches Best Friend's Cod Pot in terms of being delicious from beginning to end with no two bites alike.  ****1/2:  Attempting to judge every Eatery as an individual product of intent, execution and overall guest experience the only thing keeping Best Friend from a perfect score is that the menu seems to wander, but from someone with minimal interest in Korean Barbecue or Food Trucks everything about this place (so far) works harmoniously and its willingness to put big flavors front-and-center is a huge breath of fresh air for the tourist corridor.

FXmIZqsztXM8OUpbeDHB0g.text: Give a three star and that's being nice. A bit hyped and was disappointed. The food was okay. Kalbi was tough. Wings were soggy. The pork belly rice was mushy and over cooked. I guess you would have to be best friends to eat here. It's okay but nothing to write home about. I think after going main stream with a restaurant its losts its touch unlike the food trucks which is alot better,  which happens alot.

Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Taco were the only highlight sorry to say.
Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Not. There is no crust or no crispiness. They were soggy and not very tasty. Bland

E4Ro9WqvPRWZ41QMgxfISw.text: If you're in love with Roy Choi, then go ahead and eat here. But this is horrible food. It's not Korean food, and it's not even fusion food. It's bad food that prepared poorly and overpriced.  Granted, I only ordered the Kimchi Fried Rice, but this is a typical Korean dish that is made badly, either by design or in this particular instance, by mistake. In either case, I won't bother to spend money here again.

o41A8egPb7OCwksXbY68QA.text: Seriously no offense, but you got to be drunk to eat and enjoy the food. This place is a poor excuse for Korean/Asian Cuisine. This is a horrible disgusting display of Asian flavors. Korean chicken wings were a one note flavor of spicy and otherwise tasted spoiled. The dumpling burgers again an American play on Asian dumplings. Trash this recipe immediately and fire the guy who put this on the menu. Koji tacos that attempts to steal Mexican cuisine and does it no favors with dry meat, a soggy tortilla, and disgusting flavor profile from this drenched sickening coleslaw and once again "faux spicy Korean flavoring."  Please let's not discuss the waiters outfits. This restaurant is trying to hard to be edgy, or LA! Green Adidas track suits are a perfect match with tough urban European guys misappropriating slangs and mannerisms to be Urban/Hood.

OkeYGU7-sTfQyypgjQypGw.text: Loved everything about the place will definitely have to visit here again. Ambiance was great comfortable loud music amazing staff. The food I have no words just loved every experience they offered

FMXTt8Hd80eh5FzpTiM5tQ.text: My first time here came in celebrate our anniversary came in right as they opened got seated right away soon as you enter looks like a store then they take you pass the red blinds decor to the restaurant seating loved the vibe feel of the restaurant was little confused by who actually was a worker who was a customer everyone had normal street wear but looking at the menu had variety of options unfortunately no pictures on menu which made it little hard to pick something stayed with general stuff ordered street corn which came out delicious it was peeled off the cob and served in a bowl with all ingredients already on it also ordered the chicken which came in a hot plate still sizzling very delicious ordered the fried rice also came in a bowl little too mushy for my preference but still tasty first look I was unsure of the raw egg yolk they just tossed on top soon as I saw that mixed it in my rice too hopefully try cook it alittle with the rice still being hot not a big fan of the running yolk didn't let that from keeping me try it not bad my husband ordered the shrimp which was little spicy he also ordered the dumplings not bad we also got the duck everything looked perfect tasted delicious we were a party of 4 2 adults 2 chicken so my husband and I got pretty full not wanting to take any back home for sack of having to carry for remainder of our day.. so they serve water unless you ask for something extra to drink which was fine I was unsure of my kids with glass cups oh my lanta don't let it be my kids lol waitress was very attentive and kept coming refill our glasses food was coming out soon as it was ready which was fine we got to focus on one thing at a time try it out UNFORTUNATELY the duck came out last had a bite of the duck in the lettuce wrap right away as I tried make another wrap I noticed lettuce was dirty and I found little tiny green bugs in the lettuce let our waitress know who sent the manager you'd think he'd be shocked or something instead he says ohhh yes I'm sorry it's common because we get our supply from an organic farm we usually get worms in the lettuce ummm whatttt omg... I'm sorry organic or not all the kitchen cooks have to do is give it a good rinse and there should be no problem you think but his answer so laid back brushing it off not an answer I want to hear for the most expensive item on there menu just like nothing they took it out of our bill because of his laid back answer we didn't want a replacement plate.. place was cool different but unsure if I shall return not sure what other short cuts they take allowing to be okay

cPkFkdfiQplGO6QNUGCjjA.text: This is the best spot in Vegas. The LA Love Story tasting really portrays an upscale version of LA street food. The price is unbeatable. The food is inspired. The service is impeccable. An absolute must visit if you are in Vegas!

P8gf-JiKLuTK3Be3B_Glrw.text: Starts and finishes with great service!! We ordered the rib tacos and garlic chicken. They were both delicious! We sat at the bar because we didn't have reservation. The Bartender was super attentive and kept refilling my soda. Can't say anything bad about this place.

sef_Yp6ZC07k6aR7t-byjw.text: Was there opening night..  Service was ok.  Flavors were def different but worked for the most part.  Kimchi and fried rice were pleasantly good.  The kimchi jjigae (soup) was surprisingly bad.. it's like too much going on for a basic korean staple.  They have minor details to hash out front and back of house.  Its located near Eataly.

CAfr5dRklloyqbJbe9JHEw.text: Great new addition to Park MGM.  We were fortunate to go opening week and it didn't disappoint. The restaurant has a fun/unique bar/lobby that is super colorful and just plain interesting.  When the hostess takes you back to the main dining room you are greeted by the great fragrance of Korean bbq.  The servers wear bright jumpsuits.  Then the food, lots of great options between Korean bbq, tacos, and other tasty options.  The complementary bread is fresh baked Hawaiian rolls.  We had the spicy pork bbq (not really spicy, which worked well for us), beef tacos, and carnitas tacos.  The beef tacos were the standout of everything we ate, but it was all good.  On our next visit we will likely focus on bbq and the beef tacos.  We will certainly be back.

JGjcP8LNf8EfrcdOUaeolA.text: Good food good drinks.  I really love the Korean and Mexican fusion like their short rib tacos. the flavor of the Korean short rib in a taco was one of the best tacos that I have ever had  The watermelon hibiscus soju was very good had 3 of them, if your ever at best friend I suggest the short rib tacos, hoisin ribs and the watermelon hibiscus soju

JzxCpGTBSKadowkW9cZCtQ.text: One of the best meals we had in Vegas! The short rib tacos, dumplings and spicy pork are a must! Everyone was friendly. Price point was hood. This will be my go to restaurant!

yFEpEZVFCSkdnG6RdSj8pQ.text: 2 words. Nailed it!  Great food, great drinks, great service, and great vibe. Liked the laid back atmosphere and music. Very accommodating to people with food allergies as well. Will definitely be back next time we are in Vegas!

Wla4_JlDPz3DnNiRlI2gjg.text: I loved this place. The atmosphere was great and he food was amazing. Will be going back!!!

kXtBAnwnUabuFP4ybE30iQ.text: This place has a nice feel to it. The wall art, Staff in Adidas track suites, 80s power suites, and red cups give it that 80s break dance hip hop vibe. The pictures in the menu of young Roy and his crew was a nice touch. I have pictures like that of me and my friends that I still laugh about.  Staff was well informed of the food and ready with recommendations. I'd recommend you go with at least 4 friends as dishes are family style.  Spicy pork was spicy great. Really liked that. Garlic chicken was good. Not mind blowing, just a bit tame flavor wise. Kogi tacos are always bomb.  4 stars cause Banchan not included. What's up with that? Over all the food is good stuff. Makes me wish he'd open a restaurant off the strip with of the strip prices.

lPTGMuwkiX3EZxSO10i6Yw.text: Fist time dinning there, the experience was NOT good! I would give 1 star if I would but, 2 stars for the the service was decent.  Service was okay at beginning, but at the end when they know we were Airline crews and get discounts, the server was not too happy.  I still tipped 18% even though I felt like he thinks that we are from China and we wouldn't tip?  The food was not how I expected. Soup stew is way too thick, and a little too salty, and the Kalbi ribs are too burned. The bread and kimichi fried rice was good, but the taste of the stew and ribs are not good. Of course they aren't cheap because you are in the hotel, and you get the same amount of food at korean restaurant but doubled the price.   More importantly that I knew I left my Tom ford sunglasses there on the table, and it's hard to get through the PARK MGM security. After I spoke to security with nothing found, they told me to check the restaurant, which restaurant stayed that no one has seen anything.    I am local and I have dinning in at so many different restaurant In town and the casino, this is the Worse experience I had recently ever!  For casino standard, food is not good, service was so so, and people with no care!

JuAsAF2woTyQf0d27GmgWg.text: Went here with my partner for our anniversary tonight and we were fully blown away by everything. From the atmosphere, to the staff, to the food, everything was absolute perfection. We ordered the Korean wings, kogi short rib tacos, shaking beef saltado, and the sundae for two. I highly recommend all the dishes we ordered. Warning though, the wings definitely have a kick of heat to them so stay away if spicy isn't your thing. We will definitely be returning.

Fle0GIhkvbO9dActVQpKig.text: Yum! Glad I tried it. We had his staple short rib tacos that of course were delicious. The Garlic chicken and kimchi fried rice were amazing too!

f2zp6yE5XChbi9z4R3HI1Q.text: Such an amazing space, vibe and the food is top notch. Would not be surprised if this place starts popping up in one of the beat spots in Vegas! You need to get the Slippery Shrimp, street corn and kimchi fried rice!

qcoi0LLFT4yfP86sfsyzjA.text: 'fan of Roy Choi, this was one of the worst restaurants, particularly Korean restaurants, I have even been to. I am hoping the kitchen has an off night. The kalbi tacos were encouraging but everything behind that was super salty, unflavorful. Every single item from then on was off. Too bad. Was so excited and so disappointed. Came with ten in our party. Will not go back. Bummed.@

QGmh14OolkNe4olT95vusg.text: Always wanted to try bibiimbap as a korean novela fan and this place satisfied my taste buds! All the food was flavorful. The servers were so down to earth. The ambiance had a mixture of chill yet chic at the same time. Will definitely go back for more korean food! But they also serve mexican food.

lVt5veI7dRzMF-9QJn0AUQ.text: FANTASTIC. I've been to Best Friend twice now, the first time with a large group of girls, the second time with one friend and we sat at the bar. It was a wonderful experience both times. The staff is so friendly and fun, the manager really takes care of you. The food is delicious, don't leave without trying the Kimchi Fried Rice. We'll be back!!

u6O0vbW0yCjDFfeTBvzAZQ.text: So, cool vibe. Food is okay I guess. We got the kimchee side dish (which was not as flavorful as I would expect), kalbi ( pretty good, but wish there were half orders for 2 people), and then the banchan rice ( average and not that flavorful even with the spice sauce). I am somewhat okay with it because I don't tend to eat too salty but it is on the lighter side, which is interesting cause reviews stated that it tens to be salty. Maybe just the soups. The kimchi we got was half full compared to the 2 tables next to us who had the tin bowl completely full. Don't know how they intend to serve it, but if you are sitting next to people who got more than you and you're paying the same then you feel like you got jipped.   The reason why I gave 3 stars is mainly because of our server Korey. At first he seemed nice, but then slowly the service just went to shits. I don't know if he is aware of Korean food, but he might need to learn about it. He did come over 2x very briefly to ask if everything was okay as he was like half body walking away. He tended to larger parties more ( I get it, more tips but still man). However as we finished eating and was trying to get his attention, he was not around. I could see him and was trying to flag him down or get eye contact with him, but nope. I sat there for 13 minutes trying to flag him down to get boxes and the check. Eventually he came by AFTER he tended to the table next to us, who came in after us, finished eating after us, and they were not trying to get his attention. Then someone came and asked if we wanted our food packed. Not sure if Korey asked him to come or he was just passing by and saw us killing time waiting for something to happen. Then Korey brings the check over with the print out of the receipt and places it on the table after our food was all boxed and given to us, whereas the table next to us already paid and left. Anyway, I wanted to charge the food to the room but he ran away so fast I couldn't even tell him. I decided to just fill out the paper as it had asked about room # and what not ( with my own pen and they didn't provide one). Then was about to leave, but I know that usually they need to check ID so I decided to double check with another passing by worker. They told me to wait. We waited. And waited. Then eventually finally someone came (maybe a manager?)  and took my ID with the paper. She didn't say anything and just took it back, not very customer service friendly. Anyway, then finally Korey is the one that brings back my ID and the reciepts stating the charge to the room and to sign tip, and yet again no pen. It really isn't that hard. To be honest it wasn't even THAT busy. I've worked in a restaurant before and this service is just... Not okay. Perhaps retraining is necessary? Or perhaps going with a particular vibe for the restaurant? I don't know, but won't be coming back anytime soon.

kVijvl8FCRLR6CEu6Hw2EQ.text: Brings LA to Las Vegas. Food was freaking great and slushie hit the spot. Music was awesome and it created a great atmosphere. It's was also great seeing Roy Choi walk around. I was too shy to ask for a pic. Got to sit in some comfy ass chairs. Can't wait to come back.

lKohQllAnp4DuMGY76xq4A.text: One of my good friends from Vegas recommended we eat here during our vacay and I'm so glad she did! When we first arrived, my friends and I were super confused by how small the place was, even though it was perfectly decorated. We thought we had to order at the front, but little did we know there was an entire restaurant in the back. I was in awe at how perfect it was. The LA vibe and Korean food was the ultimate duo I didn't know I needed. The paintings on the wall are super cool and the playlist was perfect. I absolutely loved the waiters and waitresses in tracksuits! The restaurant gives off a chill LA vibe but is pretty upscale. The food is served family style so we ordered Kimchi Fried Rice, Spicy Pork, The Big E from the O.C and Elotes on the cob. We were given complimentary Hawaiian rolls, which were delicious. Everything we ordered was incredible! I love spicy pork and elotes so of course those were amazing. This was my first time trying kimchi fried rice and I'm definitely a fan especially with the egg on top! I love eating kimchi and am disappointed that I barely discovered kimchi fried rice. The Big E from the O.C was tasty, just not my favorite item we ordered. My friend ordered the Watermelon Cocktail which was pretty strong, but still tasted pretty good. The drinks are overpriced in my opinion, but considering it's Vegas and a really cool restaurant, I wasn't surprised. I'll definitely be stopping by on my next trip to Vegas!

Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy pork, Elotes, Kimchi fried rice, Big E from the O.C
Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Menu

aklK6-yHZ7mJLqM5y_E_mg.text: Allow me to start this review by saying that I am a fan of Chef Roy Choi.  As a second generation Korean American growing up in Southern California, I immediately fell in love with the flavors of the Kogi truck.  I admire and respect Roy Choi for his contributions to the community and the way that he has been able to introduce Korean food to a broader culinary audience.  With that said, you can only imagine how stoked I was to find out that he was opening a new restaurant on the Vegas strip.  Good Korean food (not just kBBQ) ON the strip is definitely something that has been a long time coming.  So while I wasn't there for the opening night, or even the first week, I made sure that it was one of the first places I visited in the new year.   We made reservations online in advance, assuming that it would be hectic and busy - and I'm glad I did.  As soon as I walked in, the decor reminded me of my parents' old liquor store in LA. There were products on display that reminded me of my childhood and some food items that screamed nostalgia. It felt like home. The staging area also serves as a bar in addition to a souvenir store for some "Best Friend" swag.  Upon checking in for our reservation at the counter, the hostess led us through to the main dining area by walking through red colored, cooler door strip curtains.  Bewildered, I just followed.  Upon entering, it feels good. The music is bumpin' - there's such a good energy to this place.  The ambience, the staff, and experience is overall positive.  Then why the 3 stars?   The food.  Again, I want to say that I "get it." I appreciate how Korean food is being elevated to a more refined dining experience. But in honest to good truth, it feels WRONG to pay $39 for soondubu, $42 for Kimchi Jjiggae, and $4 for Kimchi.  I just can't get myself to do it. So my husband and I opted to try dishes that sounded like something that we wouldn't make at home.  - The Big E from the O.C. - What I LOVED about this dish was their ponzu sauce with ikura in it -  I wanted to dip everything in that.  But just know that this dish is basically fried balls of kimchi fried rice.  It was okay. I wish I could taste more of the flavor of the kimchi and rice inside, but it's mostly all breading.   - Uni Dynamite Rice - The yuzu makes it. Sweet, savory, spicy, rich, and with a twist of yuzu.  But overall, the spiciness and the acid from the yuzu overpowered the taste of the uni.  All the flavors I wanted were present - just not very balanced.   - Slippery Shrimp - The chili mayo used for this dish tastes similar to the mayo mixture used in the Uni Dynamite Rice. The whole time I ate this, I was trying to figure out what was missing from the flavor of this dish - I wanted the shrimp to be a bit crispier... I wanted to add some more garlic. I'm not sure what it was missing.  It was just okay.  - Kogi Short Rib Tacos - I can't pass up the Kogi tacos.  It's what started it all and probably the overall favorite of our night.  But just as the Halal Guys will never taste as good in the OC as it does while you're sitting at a bench in New York City, the Kogi taco served on a plate instead of a cardboard tray just isn't the same.   We wanted to try more foods but we were so full.  As my husband and I discussed the meal, he said, "This food isn't really meant for 'us.' It's to introduce people to the idea of Korean food." And I agree.    I'm glad this restaurant is here. I know that it will be successful.  But when it comes to Korean food, my standards are high and my palette is particular.    I remember when Momofuku first appeared at the Cosmopolitan, their ramen was incredibly underwhelming.  However, in my most recent experience there, they had improved the ramen significantly. I am willing to come back and try some other things from the Best Friend menu, but maybe like Momofuku, they just need some time to adjust and fine tune their flavors.

E25ljTSNmUACbXgEUXls6g.text: This place is a traditional "Korean bbq" place, as there is no woks on the table where you cook your food.  When you first enter, you enter this hip little environment where you can stop and grab food there. However past the main area, you walk in the back and there is the main area for dinning! The waiter was super friendly and very helpful as he did recommend items to order. All the items are meant to be shared as it is a family dinning environment. All foods are a little bit more of the spicy side!  The atmosphere was very hip and trendy on the inside. All the waiters were wearing Adidas track suits which is fun! Would recommend to come here for the environment, however wasn't thrilled over the food due to the spice and variety.

hBr403s7cnWAkfHuIP5A7Q.text: Korean fusion at its finest.  The facade of the restaurant is super bizarre inside Park MGM, it reminds me of a 90s convenience store.  It had a bar on the right side, and numerous Asian snacks for sale from floor to ceiling on the left. Not really what you'd expect... but as you walk through the red sheeted factory-like "door" you're in a modern tasteful dining room.  All the staff are wearing Adidas tracksuits which is amazing!!! Takes me back to elementary school   The menu is hilarious with flashbacks of Roy and his friends in the 90s, and everything is family style and food comes when it's ready like a typical Asian restaurant.  This was reiterated to us several times by our Caucasian waiter, and were like we're Asian we got this . We ended up ordering a bunch of kogi short rib and carnitas tacos and two Chego pork belly bowl.    The kogi short rib tacos were way tastier than the carnitas tacos as the meat was more flavourful and the sauce was really delicious. Not a bad price $15 for 3 tacos, and you can add tacos at $5 each.  The pork belly bowl came and looked so delicious with the fried egg on top... and when mixed together with the egg yolk, sauce, pork belly and rice it was a delicious hot mess.  It's a misleadingly large amount of food and a very generous amount of pork belly, but everything ate well together and the sauce was a good spice level to tingle but make you want to keep going back for more. My one complaint was maybe it was a bit too saucy? But everything is a personal preference   Definitely worth checking out. Great vibe, good eats, and I would consider this a cheap eat on the Vegas strip.

photos.caption: Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States

sy9A4HQzszCxP90r5gGAFw.text: Yup yup! My boy, Roy Choi did it again. He not only topped himself but he did it in Vegas, where there are thousands of gimmicky type places on and off the strip, plus all that fine dining. His restaurant stands out as a premier food destination that does not require one to come dressed to impress. It is laid back as can be. I suggest making reservations. We dropped in on opening weekend and it was packed. Mr. Choi was there as well. I didn't want to bother him but it would have been nice to grab a pic with one of my "food" heroes. Now, I know how fans of Ariana Grande feeI.   Start off in the liquor store style front bar. You can dine there as well. Drinks are about $12, beers $10. My wife had the Hennessy and coke slushie. I went with Tiger beer. While we waited for our reservation time we chatted with the busy bartender. He was awesome!   I am familiar with his style of recipes and Latino inspired Korean fusion, but nothing prepared me for the wonderful dishes we had. Our server was wonderful. He stopped by to let us know about the place and we asked to just start bringing the food.   Dish one, order the tacos. They run about $4/each but there is no way you will find something similar to the taste near the strip. From there we had multiple dishes from the cucumbers to the slippery shrimp. We didn't order a main dish because we wanted to try small plates. We still managed to stuff ourselves. We topped it off with date cake and caramel ice cream. Very impressed with the cake. That was my first time for date cake.   Things to know, music might be loud for some inside but not unbearable. Not great for large groups, there was one room I noticed off to the side. I would not say kid friendly but did notice couple small kids.   This is one of my new fave spots in Vegas. Roy Choi did it right. Best of luck in 2019. Congrats on the new place!

KOatDP3cbrNLWGPcCbBKHQ.text: I think the best day to go to Best Friend is on Vinyl Thursday's where the DJ belts out the 90's hits. I have to say that this restaurant theme is so well thought out. Even the menu was pretty funny as it reminded me of a high school yearbook back in the day. It was so appropriate for my friend who was celebrating his "ahem" birthday.   If you are an LA native, one can appreciate the selection of food including inspirations from his various Korean and Mexican fusion foods from Chef Choi's food trucks or stores in LA. I think the food is quite pricey, but I think you are paying more so for the unique ambiance. Our waiter Korey3000 made it quite memorable. He was great in offering suggestions about the food.   The only disappointment was with the charred octopus. It wasn't charred and tasted rather bland. That dish should be removed from the menu.

-24aP8mxcLr5ct6T1o6oAQ.text: This place is awesome!  If you're wanting a quiet dining experience this place isn't for you.  BF had a DJ playing 90's rap and hip-hop totally brought me back to my days in high school! The service was excellent!  The food was amazing!  The short ribs are a must order! I will definitely be back the next time im in Vegas and most likely the times after that!

7NHG3CwigT91rHdP02fhFA.text: My family was in town for New Years and we heard they opened a "BEST FRIEND" restaurant in Las Vegas at the MGM Park hotel (Formerly known as Monte Carlo). They just recently remodel this area in the hotel so everything is nice and fresh.   I myself have never heard of this restaurant. We made a rsvp on their Instagram page (they had a link). We had a party of 14 but the max you can do on the link was 9 so we spitted our party into 2 groups (9 and 5). Our rsvp was for 8:30pm and showed up around 8pm to have a drink before dinner. The waiting area in this restaurant was GREAT! They have a lot to look at and they had a full bar. We got some drinks and the bartender DAN was amazing! He was very friendly, professional, helpful and over a great guy!   They texted us to let us know our table was ready. They ended up letting both of our party sit together. Our table was located right by the kitchen. Lucky for us Roy Choi (owner/chef) was here and greeted our table. He even took a picture with us. (so nice of him)   The food was so delicious. (look at my pictures to help you order) This is what I recommend.  *Dumplings (Pork, beef, ginger, tofu with a spicy sauce) *Elotes (Corn) *Kalbi (Korean BBQ marinated bone-in short rib) OMG MY FAVE!!! *Fries (Served with a sambal Mayo) *Kimchi Fried Rice (Caramelized kimchi, rice with a poached egg) *Kogi Short Rib Tacos (Korean BBQ, salsa roja, cilantro, onion, lime & chili soy slaw)  *Slippery Shrimp (Crispy rock shrimp, chili mayo and walnuts0 ANOTHER FAVE OF MINE! *Spicy Pork (Thinly sliced bell & shouder, kochujang and sesame)   You even get free Hawaiian bread! Yummy!!!!!   I can say I am now a fan of the food. The environment was great. It's a 80's/90's culture so be ready to step back in time! Good music, staff was friendly, good seating and overall a great place to come for dinner!

KReCRBcsLerO9fCxucN4FQ.text: Love the inside decor. Has a very hip and modern street vibe. Great restaurant to meet up with friends to have a few drinks and small bites to eat. Servers wore Adidas track suits making me wanna start b-boyin.  Breakdown of food: Eggplant: was undercooked, not one of my favorites Tacos: can't go wrong  Bimbap: it's okay, I just remember the egg was cooked correctly and nice chunks of meat. Yeah uni fried rice: it's good Garlic Chicken: yea it's chicken Dessert: Date cake awesome Nothing wowed me besides the design of the restaurant.  Music can be a bit loud in this establishment and not suitable for babies. Also price is a bit high.

bsXOhcxRYnHoO_DoFyOeHw.text: So we came by to try some of chef Roy Choi's inspirational dishes. The vibe is old school hip hop. I could do without it. The servers walk around in old school adidas running suits. Kind of boring if I'm being honest. Can see this look and hear this music at any number of restaurants in vegas and elsewhere. I was impressed the chef Roy was there cooking and coming out to the tables.  We had several dishes. The garlic chicken was very good. Used chicken thighs and it came out sizzling.  The kogi short rib tacos were good. Not outrageous. We really liked the uni dynamite rice. Just were expecting a bit of a bigger portion. Every table gets some kings Hawaiian roles that are warm and dusted with some sea salt. Again not really impressive.  The saltado was good but there was an over abundance of peppers and onions with a True lacking of protein.  I'd go back but not in a rush.

r4r1St05Nx8R32Bp3yigWg.text: If you're a hoe for the aesthetics AND the food (because you're an actual foodie and not a fraud foodie), dis the place for you.   Seriously right when you walk in - neon signs telling you what to do. Stickers. Posters. Snacks? Snacks. Merch. Cool merch. Merch that makes you buy a $27 light up coffee mug.   Roy Choi is seriously a very cool dude for bringing something truly fresh to the 702. We get a lot of LA or NYC branch offs but this is truly authentic. From the DJ to the menu typography, it really is suuuuper cool. But come for the decor, stay for the food.   We had a huge party so we ate a ton. Spicy cold noodles, wings, fries, cucumber salad, A-frame ribs, carnitas tacos, short rib tacos, etc. There's way too much to choose. That's how they get you to come back. It's a solid strategy. Everything was delicious and nothing remained. The table was a meaty carnage.   If Korean BBQ scares you, just try something new. Half of our table didn't know what banchan was but we still loved everything. Be adventurous you lil butterfly. Spread your culinary wings.   Our tracksuit-clad server Old Man Hipster (serious nametag read) was very tolerant after our multiple rounds of Hennessy and cola slushees, daiquiris, double coke and rums, and a bottle of Soju. And our loud annoying voices.  Sad because we ordered the eggplant schnitzel and it didn't get delivered to our table. But I'll be back for it. You win Choi.

LfzYusJ0IlIW0Kux25282g.text: Didn't have a reservation and when we walked in right at opening 3 weeks after they opened, still couldn't get a table so we decided to just sit at the bar and eat. With so much hype around Roy Choi opening a restaurant in Vegas, I get it, I should have made a reservation.   Let me start off by saying I Roy Choi's food in Cali. But this restaurant seemed more hype then anything.  Ordered the Kogi tacos. It was just okay. Felt like they were premade and just reheated.  Slippery shrimp was just like any other rock shrimp dish.  Uni dynamite rice, the server said it didn't come with rice, even when it is in the bowl section of the menu and he encouraged us to order a side of rice so we did. When the food came out, it came out on top of rice and we got a side of rice........... the flavor was kind of similar to the slippery shrimp.  Chego pork belly bowl looked really good in the picture but the taste was just decent. It has a mix of the pork belly with a fried egg, radish, peanuts, broccoli, and cojita cheese. Not sure if I liked cojita on it or not.  Our complimentary sweet bread came out after they delivered our 2nd dish.  Overall this place was just decent. Wouldn't go out of my way to go here.

W3uXMKjFFICspL01B3eyAg.text: I'm quite disappointed at this place, it's Korean restaurants that serves very bad Korean American food, their bbq chicken for $28 literally taste like teriyaki-chicken that is super dry, I rather go to Panda Express and get better quality food than here, also tried the Kim chee fried rice, just salty and mushy, sure it has uni but you can barely taste the uni from the overflavoring, I gave it a 2 stars because the atmosphere was very retro and trendy but food wise I say pass

AWIjJS5-3DlBYk2I0NmdZQ.text: Best Friend was such an anticipated restaurant to try! First time we came they didn't have any slots available until 10 pm without RSVP and that's when they will take walk in's.  We walked in around 10 pm after a knights game to check it out. All the food was good.   Nice ambiance of the restaurant. They do have a DJ playing so it is slightly loud but its not where you can't hear your friends to talk.  We got the Garlic chicken - I think was my favorite dish at the time. It was moist and not over cooked at all and had that nice sweet and garlicy taste  Kimchi fried rice - alright, so I liked the rice it was cooked in but the kimchi was a bit too sour. I know when its fermented the right amount of time, it gets sour. I think this time was really sour that it was just hard to get passed.  We also order the elote which I thought was delicious. It was a bit sour also but I think if you mix up the mayo with everything and spread it evenly it is quite delicious.  Watermelon Hibiscus Slushie - I also ordered a drink which I thought tasted exactly like a slushy without alcohol. it was just SO good. Make sure you mix well otherwise you'll get all the alcohol on the bottom.  Not bad, but I feel like we can get the same kinda food off strip that is just as good without the strip prices.

M5hWy8Mnl4T8I-3p-bQBhQ.text: The tacos were ok...I took a couple stars out for 2 reasons: 1 - felt rushed to eat. We even had a guy coming by asking us to eat the last dumpling because he wanted to clean the table. It was rude. 2 - with that being said, was not worth the money. We spent about $70 for 2. Too much for a fast food feeling. I wish I could actually enjoy.

505pl0gxfzwJu3ZkSJRbpA.text: A fan of everything this restaurant stands for and the thought process behind this. My reviews are generally based just on a food standpoint cause to me some of the best food can be food in the most grimiest locations.   What we (or I) ordered...  Carnitas Tacos - As expected from the creator of the Kogi truck.....fire  Fries & Sambal Mayo - The seasoning on these fries do well...we werent a fan of the Sambal Mayo though....  Slippery Shrimp - I never look at pictures of the dish prior to me trying it but heard it was a staple dish of this restaurant. Not a fan of small shrimp and the flavor tasted like the Sambal Mayo and dill...was for some reason expecting something similar to the infamous Rock Shrimp.....  Chego Pork Belly Bowl - Love everything Chego...this is FIRE  BBQ Garlic Chicken - Flavor is there and even though I prefer white meat, this dark meat chicken goodness tastes even better as leftovers  Date Cake - The toffee ice cream on this was sooo good and the date cake reminded me of something similar to sweet pancakes. Has a very Mexican inspired feel to it that I can't think of off the top of my head...  If this were just based on a food standpoint this would be a 3.5/5 but knowing how everything is being worked out in the first few weeks of opening (especially in a new market) I would most def try more items when I come back.

M8dOLdc9CJXnBtfuIVO3kw.text: I've been wanting to try this restaurant since they opened! However, as a local, I try to avoid the strip at all costs. As it was my best friend's birthday, I decided it was finally time to check this place out. I made a reservation the day before just in case it would be busy.   Upon entering, I couldn't help but look around. It's a bar area that's set up like a convenient store. They also have merchandise for sale. Super cute. The host brought us back past these red vinyl curtains and into the actual dining area. You could just tell that there was a lot of thought put into the restaurant. From the art on the wall, to the servers tracksuit uniforms, to the candles on the table, down to the menus!!! It definitely gave me 90's vibes. Our server Christina* was super sweet & gave good recommendations. You can order from a preset menu or a la carte. We decided to go with the a la carte options.   We ordered the uni fried rice, kalbi, short rib tacos, shrimp, garlic chicken, street corn, and the strawberry cheesecake. Tbh, I was so excited to eat that I forgot to take pics of most of the food :( Sorry. All I can say is that the food came out QUICK and I was satisfied with everything we ordered. Many friends recommended the kimchi fried rice, but we wanted to try the uni because it's unique! My favorites were the uni fried rice, kalbi & the short rib tacos. The flavor was spot on with all these dishes.   We also ordered a couple drinks and OMG, get the Jameson Ginger Slushee. Like, you just have to get it. So good!! They have a 16 oz or 32 oz. They get extra points for using paper straws. My straw was definitely getting soggy in my 32 oz slushee, but I really do appreciate the effort. #SaveTheTurtles.   Overall, I enjoyed my experience at Best Friend. The music was good, food was delicious, and we had excellent service. What more can you really ask for? Yeah it's a bit pricey, but that's to be expected. If you're a local that tries to avoid the strip like me, I suggest visiting on a week day so you can potentially avoid it being overcrowded. However, my server did say that there's a DJ on the weekends. I'd definitely come back for that experience. Don't forget to make a reservation!

o2NVeYCHvuS9xTa6nOlmfA.text: I am writing this while feeling completely stuffed.  My husband and I finished our meal at Best Friend satisfied and impressed at all of the flavors.  We had reservations through the MGM site and had no problem checking in.  Reservations were at 6:30 and since we were a little early (6:17), they asked us to wait just a few minutes.  We were able to enjoy the visuals of the "bodega" and grab a drink.  Husband ordered a Singaporean beer called Tiger, which he had never had.  I went with their Hennessy and Coke slushie.  Really good.  Our table was ready right on time and we were led into the dining area of the restaurant through translucent red curtains.  Look up when you walk in and you will catch a quick glimpse of the LA sky, complete with a helicopter flying by.  This is Korean-style ordering with Roy Choi's famous flair.  The menu is handed to you in a yellow 1-inch binder and with all items in large print.  Fun fact - color copies of original photos from the 90s representing the chef's roots.  It's split into several sections based on plate size with items ranging from $3 to well above $100.  There is something for every taste and palate.   My faves: bean sprout and cucumber bichon, Kogi tacos, dumplings, and the elote!    Every flavor was distinct and delicious.  They have larger plates, but we just couldn't do it.    Ambiance was chill.  Servers wore Adidas track suits, there was greenery hanging from the ceiling, LA city views adorned the walls, and a painted nopal made me feel at home.  Roy Choi himself was on site scoping everything out, probably making sure it was just right.  Definitely a must-do if you are in Vegas and love food!

photos.caption: Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Awesome decor and laid-back ambiance.
Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kogi taco - bomb!

_XpAF3n2rwDHWLoPIAeeVg.text: Asian fusion.....probably one of the worse culinary combinations ever. Other than the cool ass vibe here there is no other reason to come. The food is overpriced for what you get and doesnt really taste all that great.  Ordered from fried wings and the chicken had a dirty ass taste to it.  The uni rice had way too much yuzu in it and it overpowered the entire thing.   Tried several other dishes but they werent memorable.  Hard pass here.

2jsP1_GniMayed4_rXvRKg.text: Roy my boi, you did me dirty.   Maybe, I'm just getting too old but that music is way too loud.   The Uni Dynamite everyone was raving about was rice, uni and a whole of spicy mayo. Where was the yuzu? the sesame? That sauce just masked every other flavor that was in that rice bowl.   We also got the spicy chili cheese spaghetti. It was limp spaghetti with meat sauce from taco bell.   The best thing of the night was the free Hawaiian kings bread that came before the meal. That deserves the one extra star.   I should have stuck to the tried and True bugolgi taco/burrito.   I wanted to love it. But best friends we are not.

cJ6skwy8uH4ZJAnlJ0MsTA.text: One item checked off on my bucket list! As soon as you walk in, you get the LA vibes that Roy is so proud of and loves so much and then you are ushered into the dining area that encapsulates that vibe even more. A DJ that spins music that epitomizes LA gets you warmed up for the deliciousness that ensues. The menu is short, sweet and to the point.  It is all of Roy's creation that is the literal melting pot of dishes he is known for. If you've ever read his book and cooked some of his recipes, you know how excited I was to try this. I got the Chego pork belly bowl and this it, Chief. You have the flavors here. Sour, tangy, spicy and sweet and hearty.  I washed it down with the peach soju and some coronas and I couldn't be more happier. 10/10 would recommend for an amazing dining experience

Rje67Nnnc_EZ7FHjtT58jg.text: Great food!  Loved the kimchi fried rice and daikon. The spicy pork was too damn good.  Flavors were awesome. Lots of food best shared.  Good job Roy bringing LA to LV and Geremew, you and your Ethiopian self is fantastic!!!

5k7PBMl07F9EdYJ80xop5A.text: Wow! Roy Choi does it again. We did the Chef's choice for our party of 7 and every plate was amazing. The tacos, the buns, the steak cuts, the kimchee...it goes on and on. Thank you Christina and Scotty for the great service and treating us so good during the meal. Awesome place, highly recommend.

X13szmg3AG8bxPOYI8m9SQ.text: Great dinner with friends!  Service was wonderful and each dish was delicious!  House made kimchi - perfect amount of flavor! Dumplings with spicy dipping sauce - addictive Spicy cold noodles - these were a favorite!  BBQ Shrimp - excellent with the perfect char Kogi Short Rib Tacos - so good we ordered them twice!  Definitely recommend!  And I almost forgot the rolls!  Those things are like bites of heaven!  Warm and sweet and flaky and delicious!

KZjvhamr_dSpxXNKxZi1Pw.text: First stop once I got to Vegas and it set the bar pretty high! Amazing food, had the tacos and the street corn both super delicious!! Portions are good, many different items for sharing. Nice blend of Korean spice and savory flavors. Definitely will be returning here whenever possible!

3ax2zaU49WwrlHhk3Al35Q.text: Great concept with execution on point. A greatest hits menu of Roy Choi with a fun atmosphere. All you could want in a Vegas victory lap. Excellent wine list and other boozy options. Food truck and solid Korean food brought to a more fine dining environment. Feels like a backyard bbq and service was fantastic.

XjWrv1bSOBoHcSG0zojdPA.text: OMG!!! Never had Korean BBQ....what an amazing experience. We got the $65- 7 course option. Simply amazing. Great vibe of the place. Staff was stupid good with suggestions, recommendations, altering menu items based on taste and any allergies. Sam our server made it all the better!   I would highly recommend Best Friends! Come hungry and promise you will leave full and happy!

cnVeX6wbmlWj3YyvQWFfOA.text: Wow wow wow! My boyfriend and I came to visit Vegas and really wanted to try Chef Roy Choi's restaurant. We are fans of The Chef Show on Netflix. The food did not disappoint. Very flavorful, delicious, and large portions. The music playing music that made my boyfriend and I nostalgic, in a good way. To top it all off, my boyfriend and I were able to meet Chef Roy Choi! Shout-out to the amazing and hilarious server Scott for making it happen... the fact that Chef himself was at his restaurant speaks volumes for how much he cares and makes sure he is serving delicious and quality food.
