Z2VJjIMW1w61EJrZsDaLjA.text: Utter perfection...  This restaurant exceeds my usual "must visit" ratings. This is an ABSOLUTELY MUST VISIT while in Vegas!   Best Friend is easily a top 5 best restaurant I've ever had the pleasure of eating at!  Imagine being in Koreatown in LA. You walk past a casual Korean bbq place, pink neon signs glowing in the window. You walk inside to low tables, a casual bar, bartenders in track suits, very basic. This is the front facade of Best Friend.  Upon being greeted and checking in, here is where the fun begins...  We were greeted by a bleached blonde hostess in a 3 piece neon red suit... like, what!?   We were escorted through pink plastic curtains to a cerca 1990 LA. Absolutely beautiful and artful design. Photos of LA graffiti, low riders, LA locations. Plants hanging from the ceiling, waiters and waitresses in full neon green track suits!!!   *disclaimer, you must be in before 10pm to be serviced on the dinner menu as opposed to the late night menu*  We were sat and promptly catered to! We decided to order two of the $50 chef choice catered meal.  Being Vegas, we didn't expect much for the $50.  We were treated to complimentary Hawaiian roles topped in sea salt! Absolutely a fantastic start to the dinner!  Food came out near immediately! First plate: (normally bbq shrimp) we substituted the Korean dumplings. Slightly greasy but very savory and hearty, came with 6 for the two of us.  Next came the entree of Kimchi Fried Rice, absolutely A+, subtle crunch from the kimchi and a slight spice to the rice. Before we could even grab a scoop of the rice, the 3rd item came out: bbq chicken on a steaming metal plate!  The chicken was extremely tender, served on a hot plate with onions and subtle veggies still simmering!   Next came our traditional Korean bbq small sides of spiced broccoli, kimchi, and spicy cucumbers.  As we dusted off the kimchi fried rice... it kept coming!  We were blindsided when the track suited waiter came back with ANOTHER steaming plate, this time bbq pork on a bed of onions! Our table over flowing with plates at this point, we gladly accepted the food. Accompanying the pork came a bowl of white rice.  The pork was tender, near melt in your mouth with a nice char flavor from the bbq!  Another plate! Out came the Korean tacos with a bbq beef as the meat... utterly fantastic!  We slowly grinded to a halt, stuffed to the brim.   Think about it, how often are you ever stuffed to the brim on $50 in Vegas? That's nearly unheard of!  Hoping to be greeted by the bill, it wasn't over. Mercifully our dessert came rolling out. A strawberry cheesecake with strawberry sherbet. A perfect sweet "cherry on top" to a killer good Korean BBQ meal!  I have rarely been this satisfied with a meal, or utterly saying "wow" out loud to the presentation or flavor of meals.  You HAVE to visit this restaurant while in Vegas! If you are a fan of bbq, this is absolutely your spot! Definitely one of the more affordable sit down options in Las Vegas and the atmosphere is next to none!

1uIivqsD7bxGusateRnaSw.text: A fabulicious time we had here at Best Friend. Bumped into this spot quite by chance. Lucky in finding a reservation the following evening.  Exhilarating is the walk from their neon bar thru their 'red'.  Stepping into an intoxicating dimly lit scene filled with hip hop music and exotic murals.   Enticing was our dinner of buttery "Hawaiian Rolls; crispy "Korean Fried Chicken";  flavorful "Kimchi Fried Rice"; and, super juicy "Spicy Pork Tacos".  Incredible, informative, and efficient also was our server.  A lasting dope impression this restaurant made.  Am already looking forward with my dinner here next in trying even more tantalizing dishes.  CHEERS!

942tQNDj6qbE4CrbaNBy2Q.text: I've been wanting to try one of Roy Choi's places for some time ever since I heard of the Kogi food tucks and restaurants in LA.  Being close to LA is ironic I've ever tried one of his spots until now.  When the Monte Carlo became the park MGM i was most excited about trying Best Friend.    Best Friend is an experience to be had.  You first walk into a what looks like a liquor store, which is the restaurants sports bar area.  The shelves are stocked with items that you would find in a mini mart and there is even merchandise that you can buy.  As you wait to be seated you go through a red partition and it's like you're being transported to LA, Roy Choi grew up in.  The dinning area is darkly let and there are TV's showing familiar sights of LA there is even booming music featuring west coast rap.  The decor was nice, during our time there many guest were taking pictures of the decor, because it is so cool The LA theme in there is so nice it made me want to put on an LA Dodgers fitted cap.    Their are a lot of options for food and price points too.  I think the Vegas menu buy for is the most expensive, but the LA menu has some favorites I believe are from some of Roy Choi's other spots.  The Menu I went with is the LA menu.  We got the Kogi tacos (of course!) and some spicy shrimp with a side of rice.  Both items were excellent the shrimp was very flavorful and had a unique taste and the tacos were what I expected too as a great example of fusion tacos.    This place right here is probably the best reason for you to come to Park MGM if you are visiting.  The experience and the food were both equally amazing, if you're looking for experience or place to take a group of people for dinner Best Friend does not disappoint.

photos.caption: Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Can&#39;t wait

TH5qk7A1fYgWTaz76SMZPQ.text: I came to Best Friend shortly after visiting a few authentic Korean restaurants in Koreatown L.A. I thought it would be interesting to compare tradition with modern Korean fusion food.   Food 3/5: All of the savory dishes that I sampled were heavily spiced and overly salty. I tried the Chego Pork Belly bowl, Slippery Shrimp, Silken Tofu and the Bingsu for dessert. My favorite was the Bingsu.   Atmosphere/Vibe 5/5: I loved the atmosphere inside the restaurant. It was modern with an urban street aesthetic. The candle-lit tables and lighting were dark overall, but the servers wearing bright Adidas jumpsuits was a neat contrast. The couch/cushion chairs were very comfortable.   Price 3/5: It wasn't overpriced, but the pricing was on the higher end. We had a party of three and spent $75 which did not include any drinks.   Service 5/5: Servers were attentive and friendly.   Tips: Don't expect to take decent Instagram shots here. It's very dark.

photos.caption: Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Bingsu, shaved ice with prickly pear sorbet
Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Slippery Shrimp (spicy mayo sauce)
Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chego Pork Belly Bowl

BsLmVkE4oCFfi2Mgn_6bRA.text: My friends and I spontaneously decided to eat here for dinner on a Thursday night in Vegas! Tip: make a reservation!! Unfortunately it was booked for almost two hours so they gave us the option to sit at the bar and it was the same menu, which we agreed to! Honestly I didn't even care because the food was AMAZING.  My group of friends and I got the pork belly bowl, short rib tacos, street corn, and the uni rice bowl. Everything was delicious and I wish we had room to try more stuff on the menu! Definitely check this place out if you're trying to eat some unique fusion food in Vegas!

We had gone to celebrate a birthday and had taken my cousin who was visiting from Hawaii.  Turns out the concierge put us down for the wrong day and wrong number of people. Seemed that the concierge was only interested in getting me signed up for their rewards card.   She had even read back the reservation to me and it was correct. Also just be sure that you know this place is location is not at MGM - So don't park at MGM otherwise it's going to seem like a 2 mile hike to get to Park MGM! avlybTVubsdKV0s66UKGsg.text: Suggested by my cousin and fellow Yelper, Mallori P, this was on the list for our trip to Vegas! A Kogi truck fan, we knew we had to eat here!  If you do one of the pre fixed for $50 you get his famous specialties! Short rib tacos, slippery shrimp, kimchi fried rice, beef bulgogi, garlic chicken, buchon, date cake! All the food is on the spicier side, so keep the order of homemade Hawaiian rolls coming! All food is served family style! Very casual vibe!

Qc6eYe72DS1UP9N8A4bSyg.text: One word can truly describe this place: AMAZING!   I was in Las Vegas for a long period of time and had the opportunity to eat here many times during my visit. Each time I was never disappointed. I usually sat at the bar. It is a cool vibe inside and the bartenders were awesome! Good service and the food came pretty quick. Every time I ate here I got the cucumbers because they were so refreshing with a little spice to it. I would have to say my favorite dishes were the clams, tacos and kimchi fried rice (seen in pictures).   If you are ever in Vegas this is a MUST TRY!! You will not be disappointed. When I go back, I will try out more menu items!

SQ9YCrPUBBbS-EnOz4U5vQ.text: When LA goes to LV! Roy Choi combines all his LA spots and mixes in some LV flare.   Located in Park MGM right next to Eataly.   Reservations were easy to get the week of for a weekend dinner. It did not look busy from the outside but it was pretty packed inside.  There is an outer inside bar seating area and a inside restaurant seating area.   Service was good. Food comes out really fast. Prices are inflated for LV.   Good Day Soju - $25 - Probably a 5 dollar bottle for 25 bucks!  Hawaiian Rolls - Complementary - King's Hawaiian but fresh and way better.  Kimchi - $4 - Flavorful with mild heat. Small ban chan style dish. Broccoli - $4 - Crispy broccoli. Good dish to cut the heavy food.  Street Corn - $10 - Elotes but cut off the cob. Slippery Shrimp - $18 - Spicy version of the walnut shrimp dish. I liked the heat. Kogi Short Rib Tacos - $15 - If you had the truck, you know they are bomb. You get 3, can add additional tacos for 5 bucks each. I do not think the truck even charges this much for a taco though.  Korean Wings - $15 - Crispy batter. Light heat in the sauce. One of my favorites from the meal. Kimchi Fried Rice - $15 - Tastes like the name, kimchi mixed with fried rice. Small bowl for the price.  Garlic Chicken - $24 - Worst dish we had. Chicken was like fast food teriyaki chicken with less flavor.  Prices here are a lot more then you pay at his LA joints but still had a good overall meal.

ia7-VecJW2LTdBVN3RMVkw.text: First timers here. Make a reservation or you won't be eating here.   We had the chef's menu. So much food we had to have it packed up to go.   The tacos were good. The veggies were good, but I'm not one for spice, so... No kimche for me. The shrimp was amazing. The beef was awesome. We ate the deconstructed strawberry cheesecake before I could get a pic   The service is great. They explain how everything works and make great suggestions. Food came out quickly and it was hot and flavorful. I would definitely do it again. Except I ain't coming back to Vegas #vegassucks

XsrCFX9bfA9Ziy9ifrOZrQ.text: Go Go Go!! We had not one but two amazing dinners here while staying at the Park MGM. Both night we sat and the bar with Ghonk and had an amazing experience and the best food.  The restaurant itself is extremely fun looking and provides a nice casual vibe for dinner.  The Kimchi Fried rice is still giving me dreams. The spicy pork is a great shareable dish with a side of rice.  The veggie Tempura is huge and well executed.  You must must must get a Margarita or the Thai Long Island Ice Tea both were so fresh and a spin on the classic cocktails we all love.  I will for sure be back to Best Friend, I can not wait to explore other items on their menu!

We walked in and there were no tables available.  We found a spot at the bar and the bar tender was very nice.  He let us take out time looking at the menu. The food came out quickly and everything was really delicious!    I can't wait to go back!  They also have some nice merchandise.

Went for dinner with friends and the pulsing beat made talking nearly impossible. BBQ Spicy pork was the favorite, but the Octopus appetizer was too light on the octopus.

It was hard to believe this place has only been open a few days.  The staff there were great (Danny was our server), he made some great recommendations, and treated us like we were all best friends.  The food part was so good.  Only comment was we may have ordered too much, but on a positive side, that meant we got to try more things.  Favorites were the Galbi and Garlic Chicken.  Great size portions for sharing, so bring your best friends and order a lot of different things.

Went at 915p on a Saturday after a show and a place like this should have it together, but staff seemed to be doing prep work for next day already, and even though the place was only half full drinks took forever. I really hope they improve the service and get dialed in because the food is delicious, of note the short rib tacos and the kimchi rice.

pzzV1GOjkdtvihGt3TnQCA.text: Pretty theme-y. Foods good but not outrageous. If you like spice go here. DJ was on point! Music so good!

W5eHlsiNxdX820jafUjJWA.text: Make reservations! I didn't think they'd be booked but they were and I didn't have a reservation. Luckily they were able to seat us at a later time. Food was absolutely delicious! There were 3 of us and ordered about 6 things off the menu and that was enough. Pork Belly Rice Bowl was my favorite! Service was great but still needs some improvement. I get it, the place is new so it takes some time to work out the kinks. Server was not as attentive but he was running around so understandable. 3rxuhah7B0W-aH4RSfgARQ.text: I wanted to like you best friend but after eating there tonight I can't. I went with my family we had easy orders and we weren't there at rush hour but at 10 pm. The decor was nice the food was very good but it fell apart at service. Our server, Danny was very nice but forgot my father's beverage. He wasn't sure what my sister in law ordered, she clarified and when the food came out hers was still wrong. Then we sat there with our dirty plates just waiting for someone, anyone to clear them away. Someone who looked like a manager passed by us over 5 times and never did a thing, what are you managing? I think the server bailed on us after making a mistake on the order, come on really? When he finally did show up again, "you want the check?" Well I was going to have dessert, but now I won't. He left again never took even a plate with him, and there we sat with dirty dishes in  a restaurant that wasn't half full. To add insult to injury when he did finally show with the check we were charged the wrong price on the banchan and charged for the mistaken item. I thought you were my best friend :(

3OVjnoI8-RvXBl1qKCzt_A.text: This place is a must!!! If you love Korean food, this spot is perfect. The decor is super flashy, tacky, the staff are cool (so are the drinks!) and the food is amazing. We found this place when we were in Vegas last month and now visiting again I had to take my mom for late night Kolgi tacos. They're just too good with tender meat and the spices plus the slaw - it's the perfect late night (or any time) bite. On my previous visit we had the kimchi fried rice which is perfection, spicy kimchi fried rice wth a buttery sunny side egg on top plus the salty seaweed mmmm! The prices aren't bad, it's inside the Park MGM but only open til midnight so make sure to squeeze this spot in, it's so worth it! Round out your trip here with a Jameson and ginger slush and you'll be on your way to a great night!

We almost didn't get to eat here, but a last minute cancellation saved us  We had: Korean ribs Spicy pork Street corn Cucumbers with some kind of spicy dip  Pros: Service was excellent  The bread they start you with is GOOD DJ spins amazing late 90's-early 2000s bangers Food was on point The frozen Hennessy/coke slushy may have been one of the best things I've ever had  Cons: A bit pricey (but hey, it's Vegas) The Korean Ribs were just a little bland (but still delicious)  Would 100% come back here

mXtOnkfgEPIzFN02jZoRbg.text: I haven't set foot in a Roy Choi restaurant since A-frame, which was nearly 5 years ago. I was excited that he decided to open up an LA-inspired restaurant in Vegas. The concept is a throw-back to the 90's and brings back some nostalgic vibes down to the menu, which features some high school dance photos. We've all done those poses with the hair. The feel of the interior is very LA. Also I love the front bar, which is reminiscent of the pawn shop at Beauty & Essex.  We came the day after the grand opening and this place was packed. If you were to dine here, come with 4-6 people because the menu is made for family-style dining. It was a little disappointing to see that the side dishes were $3 when they could be found to be complimentary at any KBBQ place around town, but hey, it's in an MGM property and money is to be made. The menu is broken down by dish size starting with a few appetizers, rice bowls, BBQ, LA-inspired plates, large shared pots, and finally large format plates.  We started with the Korean wings with chili, citrus, and lychee ($12) which come with 4-6 wings. The wings are small, but pack a big flavor punch. I was a fan and liked these a lot. For bowls, we went with the uni dynamite rice ($17) and the chego pork belly bowl ($15). The uni dynamite rice was my favorite and has large pieces of Santa Barbara uni covering a rice bowl with dynamite sauce that would usually cover sushi rolls, sriracha, yuzu, and sesame. The pork belly bowl had nice crunchy pieces of pork belly with a fried egg, radish, broccoli, peanuts, and cotija cheese, which was an interesting topping, but worked. Of the two, get the uni.  We decided to skip the KBBQ portion of the menu, since they seemed straight forward and did not offer anything different than what you might find at a KBBQ place. For the L.A. SH*T portion of the menu, they were all out of elotes, but we did get the slippery shrimp ($16), A-Frame OG ribs ($18), and eggplant schnitzel ($18). The slippery shrimp were a table favorite. The rock shrimp were crispy and went very well with the chili mayo and walnuts. It would've been nice if they used giant prawns like how Chinese restaurants would with their walnut shrimp dish. The A-frame OG ribs were a huge disappointment. The rib meat was the opposite of fall-off-the-bone and the hoisin-chili sauce was nothing to write home about. The eggplant schnitzel, on the other hand was nicely fried and a unique addition to the menu.  For large pots, I highly recommend the tamarind black cod stew ($44). This was quite spicy, in a good way, and large enough to share between 5 people. This was probably my favorite dish of the night. The cod was perfectly cooked and flaked right off. For large format dishes, we got the lobster kung pao ($78). Not really worth the price for Maine lobster for the size we got. The flavor was good, but there just wasn't much meat at all.  Overall, I loved the family-style dining and shared format. The food was good for the most part and the portions were large and filling. We could've probably done without 1-2 dishes as we left full enough to skip dessert. I would definitely return for the large shared pots, especially that tamarind black cod stew.

x4e7Hb_qUx2AMNhW902tng.text: I love Kogi so I had very high expectations for Best Friend. I wasn't disappointed. We went to Park MGM in hopes to be able to be seated at this restaurant and luckily, we were able to be seated at the bar area. The lady in the front told us that if we wanted a seat in the restaurant, the next time available was 9:30pm or so (on a Friday night), which was too late for us since it was barely 5:30pm during that time! I actually prefer sitting at the bar counter because we were able to see all the drinks and the alcoholic slushies at a better angle as well as converse with the bartender more.  Service: Friendly and informative. The bartender we had was very observant and anticipated our needs. He gave us really solid recommendations and we were so happy that we balled out a little ($$$). Roy Choi, you know how to win us.  Ambience: The restaurant looks very hype with stickers and magazine cutouts everywhere. The use of neon lighting and items nostalgic of our childhood was also everywhere. The vibe and the ambience was also very 90s and hip!  Food: We had the kimchi fried rice, the fries, the dumplings and the bulgogi plate. All were delectable and I had no complaints. Flavored well and had an array of textures. The waatermelon & hibiscus soju slushy ($18 for 16oz or $38 for 32oz) was really delicious. It wasn't too strong in alcohol and also wasn't too sweet. I almost wanted to not share this one!

QivKU4F1r8nHDrJYx8pasQ.text: 3 stars, 1 for the great service from our server. He was attentive, thoughtful and knowledgeable about the menu.  We ordered the broccoli banchan, kimchi fried rice, grilled octopus, and spicy cold noodle.   The food was not as impressive as the decor and service. First and foremost, the dishes came out cold. Seems like the food was sitting on the counter for a bit before they were brought out? I was expecting the rice to be steaming and cooking in the pot, so when the food was served at almost room temperature we were definitely disappointed.   The cold noodle was also too tangy and spicy. The flavor was overwhelming and we had to guzzle down glasses of water in order to finish it. The noodles were also quite soft and lacked the chewiness that I'm used to when I usually eat korean cold noodle.   The octopus dish was my favorite. The portion was generous, and the gochujang flavor paired well with rice. The flavor is again, very bold so if you are sensitive to salt I would not recommend ordering.  Overall, I was not thrilled about our meal but it could be that we did not get to meet dishes that match our palette. Especially because we really enjoy Chego and Kogi, we still have hope to find something we'll love.

Lc5J693bPoUFE5Cv42iYAA.text: From the ambiance down to the detail in the food it was great! I had the Korean Tacos and they had so much kick and flavor.

photos.caption: Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Had to keep it TX in Vegas by drinking a corona.

mhoQ0Hi-m_A1ALL0IKWqHA.text: Normally skeptical about eating any Asian food on the strip. But I have to say was I pleasantly surprised with how everything tasted. We got the combo B set course. Started a little slow with banchan (small vegetable dishes to start a meal). But when the dishes started coming out, everything was great! Kogi tacos was sweet on the initial bite, and had a good flavorful spicy hot on the second. The dumplings is not what I'm used to having traditionally, but very well meshed with the dipping sauce. The bbq prawns had a good citrus flavor. The kimchee fried rice could have been more spicy with gochujung, but not everyone likes spicy food. The bulgogi ribeye was cooked perfectly, and the citrus sauce was a nice touch. The best part was the cheesecake! So far the best part of my trip thus far. The way they presented everything, and flavors are ingenious.

-nDnH9PnksqRPVecdFmwwA.text: 310, 818, 323 and the 213 just landed in the 702!  As soon as my wife and I (we just moved to Vegas about a year ago from LA), heard Roy Choi is opening a spot out here, we jumped on some reservations for Best Friend!  The space looks really unique, from the front entrance, which is also their bar, dubbed "The Liquor Store", I feel like you're going through a story book of Roy Choi's upbringing in the city of LA. This front section is also where you and your bestie can get some fresh Best Friend merch.  Going through the menu, I immediately wished we were a group of at least 6, cause, I wanted to order the whole menu. However, since there was just the two of us, we ordered ONLY: The cucumber-banchan, kimchi, Slippery Shrimp, Spicy Pork and the Kogi Short Rib Tacos. Also, included in the meal, was some complimentary Hawaiian style rolls.  Their Slippery Shrimp was my favorite. It had some warm, underlying heat and some next level flavors. I could've eaten two plates of that on my own! Their Spicy Pork is top shelf Korean BBQ, their tacos, if you've ever had Kogi Tacos, are basically the catalyst to pretty much 97% of any food truck making it in America today. So they should all pay homage to this taco. The cucumbers, man, those cucumbers! No joke, I may come back just for these. Easily, one of the best sides I've had in a restaurant period! Simple in execution, but with tremendous flavor. Often, the simplest dishes are the easiest to screw up. Their Kimchi was on point as well, probably the best I've had, certainly the best in Vegas. Last but not least, their homemade Hawaiian rolls were phenomenal. I was using them as a vessel to scoop up some meats and sauces along the way!  Again, I wish I could've ordered more. I wanted one of their pot-dishes SO bad, so I'll definitely be back to try those.  Service was extraordinary, from our hostess, to the person who sat us and finally to our waitress, Stacy; everyone was very friendly and genuinely looked like they were having a great time.  Glad Best Friend is finally here, glad they're in an up-and-coming spot like the Park MGM, glad they're repping LA! I highly recommend this spot, and don't forget, when you come, bring yo Best Friend ;)  Food: 5 Ambience: 5 Service: 5 Value: 5

Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The &#34;Liquor Store&#34;; their bar and merchandise area

Yr0MjvwreQCB4gZy3No8zQ.text: We were here on a Monday with 8 o'clock reservations. First, the entire restaurant is a throwback to the 1990's which I love! From the decor to the music and even the server's outfits.   Our server, Corey, was funny and full of information. He asked about food allergies. He made it appoint to separate the dishes with shellfish from the ones that did not and then explained which was which.   We had the priced  meal for $50 a person. It was more then my husband and I could finish. We had the Korean BBQ street tacos, kimchee, Beef, fried rice and white rice along with date pudding and some other dishes. My husband drank a delicious whiskey slushee.  The food, service and ambience was great! We will return and highly recommend it.

g04n8I-pzgshPnyAc0UTDA.text: Best Friend by Roy Choi was a culinary experience. I actually had to go back and revisit past reviews for which I granted five stars, because after trying this restaurant THIS IS FIVE STARS. From the moment you go in thru the red curtains, you can smell the delicious food coming out of the kitchen.  So many, good options it is hard to make a decision! Each plate was unique and flavorful ! I loved the decor of the restaurant, very urban-hipster. The service was impeccable. The flavors, dear lord the flavors... let's just say after eating here I am spoiled!   Remember to make reservations, this place was packed on a Monday night.  During our lovely dinner, I noticed that Chef Roy Choi himself was supervising the plates coming out of the kitchen and bringing plates to the tables! He even agreed to a selfie!

The fry portion was huge. The mango Budino was the perfect end to this fantastic meal. I will definitely be back and would recommend this place to all my friends who live locally.

iEmnlmgCNUJ-eML2tI0Vgw.text: Eager to return.  We popped in on NYE without a reservation and quickly found a couple seats at the bar for a light dinner.  The creative frozen cocktails (think Hennessy frozen daiquiri) were fun but the Kogi short rib tacos for $12 were phenomenal.  I could have easily eaten another full order of 3. I truly have to complement MGM for what they have done to the old Monte Carlo. While they have may have ripped off the Cosmopolitan model, the place is fun and the new restaurants (Best Friend, Eataly) and bars are great.

Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States

R5sE7r2msKBVrG3BSXlQnw.text: Food looks great, the location is amazing but, hostess insisted it was reservation only.  She failed to inform us that we could have reserved a table online then & there, & we would of only had to wait 20 minutes.  Due to her lack of communication we left and ate elsewhere. We came from California to support our friend's new restaurant. We're fans of his la location as well. But I guess this time it just didn't work out smh

6aWBFXapNG6CT1ckl8y2wA.text: Among the first patrons to experience this restaurant opening night and it was great. When you first enter before you get to the restaurant there's a bodega where you can shop for quirky best friend souvenirs and tasty snacks like instant soups, chips, classic 90s candies, etc. There's also a bar inside the bodega where you can order choice cocktails or even a Hennessy and cola frozen drink. Dope!   We had a 5pm reservation and entered the back restaurant area where we were greeted with servers dressed in Adidas track suits, beautiful murals on the walls reminiscent of Long Beach or Venice Beach, and LA hip hop music. The menus were sort of similar to a family photo album and had old pictures of Chef Choi, family, friends mixed in with the actual entrees. The prices range from about $10-50 depending on what you get, but they encourage sharing  so it's really not bad per person.  They had things like elote, traditional Korean meats like kalbi and marinated pork, kimchee fried rice, shrimp, hot pots, tacos, etc. We ordered a few different things to share and everything tasted good and we left full and happy. Chef Choi checked on us several times and stopped to greet us and take a pic (Yay!). Overall it was a great opening!

photos.caption: Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Inside decor
Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Meeting Chef Roy Choi!
Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Frozen cocktails in the bodega

zzb2-7bmx5Wzv8Vm9sEWdQ.text: Went around 9:00pm and had to wait 45 minutes for four people. location is in a casino so that time was easy to kill. there's a lot going on environmentally in the restaurant when you first enter! it felt like an underground club but cleaner.   we got the garlic chicken, kimchi fried rice, and kogi tacos. everything was delicious!

Qlp8J3WqfOCQGb2v0RqYAw.text: Awesome place to try in Las Vegas. The restaurant and staff are all really cool, hip, and fun. If you come for drinks or food you'll really enjoy just being there. As far as the food goes it is all stand out. Instead of having to pick an app and entree for dinner we order the chefs selection for $50, it is mix of about eight of the popular items on the menu. Its perfect because you get to try so much of the menu and each item is amazing. I think the shrimp and ribs were my favorite items but everything is really good. Stop by and go.

photos.caption: Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Two types of tacos.
Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States

ZN4nLw4HjekuzIxqr66Qsg.text: Best Friend by Roy Choi is amazing not only for the food but also for the atmosphere.  I grew up in Las Vegas and moved out to LA five years ago and Roy does an amazing job at bringing Los Angelean fare to The Strip. My boyfriend and I booked a reservation for the soft opening a week or two ago and it was the only thing we had planned for this trip and we weren't disappointed!   The entry room/merch/bar area is super cute and themed so well. The art direction behind every little thing from the outfits the hosts wear to the low key menu is incredible. They play great music that isn't too loud but loud enough to have a good time.   We ordered the kogi tacos, elotes, spicy pork bbq and kimchi fried rice for our meal and everything was INCREDIBLE. We also ordered the date cake which was phenomenal and I highly recommend it to those who like sweets that aren't over the top sweet.   Our waiter was incredible and it was cool to see the man himself, Roy Choi, walking around in the restaurant. We definitely will be returning this week (hoping to try the King Pao Lobster as an early birthday present )

photos.caption: Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kimchi Fried Rice
Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kogi Tacos
Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy Pork BBQ

UCYhlUs9iaXIFKUqv2hQbg.text: I'm a big fan of Roy Choi so when I heard about Best Friend, I knew my family had to try it while we were in Vegas for the holidays. The restaurant, with its neon signs and bodega-style storefront, was easy to spot inside Park MGM. We were 20 minutes early for our reservation on Christmas Eve but they were able to seat us immediately.   We were unfamiliar with the menu, but our server was super friendly and helpful in deciding what to get and how much to order. We decided on the cucumber & spinach banchan, chego pork belly bowl, spicy pork belly, and spicy cold noodles, which was the perfect amount of food for 3 people. Everything was sooo delicious and bursting with flavor, and I loved that they brought out chopsticks for us in a novelty LED cup. The servers also brought out complimentary bread rolls that were warm, buttery, and delicious. I also got a Jameson & ginger slushie drink, which was delicious albeit on the weak side and a bit pricey. They also had watermelon soju and henny & coke slushies.   Overall I was very impressed with the atmosphere, food, and service at Best Friend and I'll definitely return next time I'm in Vegas!

photos.caption: Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Jaymo &amp; Ginger slushie, bread rolls, spinach banchan, cucumber banchan
Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Entrance area
Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chego pork belly bowl

zgEr7JEiR7W5ZMI31BioAw.text: Convenience of late hours makes this place a win. I have tried almost every restaurant in LA that Roy has; Chego, A-Frame, Commisary, Locol, and Kogi. However I was most excited to try Best Friend. The food was great, as to be expected. Prices are "Vegas" prices, so that is what it is. I do have a couple gripes that dampened my experience. Food timing was awful, in our group of 4, we each got our dishes separately spaced 20-30 mins apart. Secondly, the server didn't seem too attentive to his tables, and this was evident in the body language of both tables next to us, as we all were wondering where he was all night. Otherwise, the decor is amazing and the vibe is cool. I am still a fan of Roy and will continue to support, as this experience was more on the service rather than the food.

jozNLDgJgpM9U2CRT4Wyiw.text: Excited to see and taste all the new spots that Park MGM has to offer! Came to Best Friend on Christmas Day, made a reservation but it wasn't super packed. Upon entering, the layout and decor of the bar area and hostess stand was pretty creative. The displays of Asian snacks and having a bar out front definitely gives opportunity to customers who just want a quick bite and drink. Walking through to the actual restaurant, the walkway made it seem like we were entering a meat storage, with the red plastic strip door curtains, felt like we were about to enter a new world. The dining area I loved, it felt very esthetic and homey at the same time. Murals of Roy and his friends and family on the wall, the choices of rugs and tables/chairs made it feel like we were at a friend's house. Love the choices of attire for the servers, tracksuits . It was time for the food and being a fan of Korean and Mexican food, i was excited to see how the fusion would come about.   Food:  Buttered Hawaiian rolls- free refills and probably one of my favorites from the whole entire dinner.  Kalbi- tender, but definitely was too charred and didn't taste like it was marinated enough.  Korean chicken wings- Tasted too much like buffalo wings, did not taste similar to typical kfc at other Korean spots.  Soondubu- Definitely LARGER than I thought it would be and it comes with rice! Although, I was disappointed in this dish. It tasted like they dumped a whole container of the red paste and not much flavor. Definitely too spicy, even the table beside us agreed that it was too spicy.  Mango Budino- My top favorite of the night! It was soft, not super sweet, and good size!   Overall, the concept of the restaurant I do like, but some of the dishes so far could need some work. Next time, I would try some other entrees/ sides, but so far I know what I would not try again.

dDDZxcjQpPJxf2gZUdMFJQ.text: I live in Los Angeles and I came to visit my parents for the holidays, we came here together and had the BEST time. The atmosphere was killer... so much to look at, take pictures of, and the food was delicious. Every inch of the restaurant has something to stare at. The drinks were very creative and crafted to perfection (as a bartender myself I'm picky and they were great).  The watermelon cocktail is a MUST TRY. Our waiter was Sam & he was forsure our best friend by the end of our meal. Sam recommended everything for us because there was so much to choose from we were a little overwhelmed-job well done! We were so impressed and will 100% be back.

lmlH8wESUuFEAhu5s5J2ng.text: Small portions but delicious. Loved the atmosphere but the chairs were hard to get into and out of. Also, it was hard to eat because the lounge chairs were so large. Nonetheless, I'd go back.

QjpohZGfaI1HHynKo92UNQ.text: Great scene and amazing food.  4 of us went and probably split 15 items and all of them were really good.  The tomahawk steak was one of the best steaks I've ever had.  Give it a shot

_g8XkOO7T8wP8Qo1H0l8sA.text: Thought I was coming here to enjoy dinner with my best friends- it was like a mix of being in a tropical club? The music was so loud I couldn't even hear my friends... the waitress accused me of ordering French fries and not the Uni dynamite rice ... didn't apologize for her mistake and continued to blame me even though I told her twice what I ordered. The food was too spicy. Almost everything had spicy aioli. Uni should be served by itself to enjoy, instead I was eating rice and lemon, a lot of spicy aioli with some Uni mixed somewhere. Should just put on your menu Spicy Aioli with a side of whatever. Not impressed. Overpriced and rude staff. Wouldn't take anyone here even for the experience! Portion sizes are not shareable sizes too. I could keep going but what's the point. Hyped this place up too much. Sorry.

Ar08dFcpMCUbwcsreCBRXw.text: Amazing...amazing...amazing. Dumplings were to die for. We got the pre-fix menu and everything was so tasty. The Korean tacos were also superb. Probably the best food we have had in Vegas the whole trip. Go here!!!

cwYScDjVGA13Xtg1SRFh3g.text: Don't get it and can't imagine it will last. Overpriced pretty average food. Put a poached egg in some sticky rice and $120 for some spare ribs? An extra star because staff were trying and actually seemed to care. Give it a miss!

DOEidMRxaStsI1mrgcdArw.text: I was so excited for this place! I live in So Cal and think of Roy Choi's as part of a culture I love. To be fair this review is based solely on two dishes. The Lobster Kung Pao and the Korean BBQ Ribs. The ribs were super mediocre. I've had better at any number of hole in the wall places around the country. They were tough and a mostly flavorless. And served on a giant bed of raw onion. Huh? But the Lobster Kung Pao was terrible. And 85$! Not only does the preparation and presentation make it nearly impossible to dig out the lobster but the spices totally overwhelm it. So you might as well be eating chicken for 1/4 the price. Service was great and the place has a fun vibe.

JFgrIDhuyDEg7CarODf1bA.text: So when we ask you what's good, don't say "everything's really good, there's nothing that's not good, and we turn hundreds of people away every night." How about telling me what you like the most and then going from there? The food is okay, it's nothing special. We got a variety of things from dumplings to bbq shrimp and kalbi, pork rice, kimchi arincini. They were all okay, not great, not bad. Not sure what the hype is all about, it's just another restaurant that offers average food with so so service.

D3wRIiFk8HVafKlcqlKULw.text: For food to be memorable, it must be quite unique, delicious, has depth to it. This restaurant has yet to learn how to cook the meats right. What they have done is to mix the meats with Korean sauce with Mexican sauce. They have totally neglected that the meat quality.   In this restaurant, the primary purpose of all dishes is to "fusion" good Korean dishes with Mexican flavor.   A party of three came here for dinner. We ordered  Tamarind Black Cod Stew Crispy Shrimp BBQ chicken wings.  If you like garlic, cilantro and hot sauce, you will feel quite at ease. But the quality of the meat is missing: e.g. The Black Cod Stew, fish meat can hardly be found, has no structure and when you do find it, it is in small pieces and they are all mushy.   The sauce on the chicken wings is tasty. But the chicken wings meat is totally tasteless and the meat is soft and mushy.  Even the shrimp is soft and mushy , there is no body to the meat.   This is definitely a NO for me. Just because some one thinks of mixing two complete different sauces together, does not make him a good chef nor a good meal.  Pricing is reasonable for a strip restaurant. Ambiance is for the younger crowd - noisy but orderly. service is good.   All in all, very disappointing.

GSJBjKTjwswIJKHxzYXEsw.text: Im a big fan of both Korean and Mexican and while they do have offerings of both styles of food i really didn't see the fusion between the two at Best friend. It was more Korean than Mexican.  I ordered the Kogi Tacos and KimChi Fried Rice. I shared the tacos, 3 tacos per an order, and they were very good I could've eaten two orders by myself. The Kimchi fried rice was very heavy and rich would recommend sharing and not as a meal in its self. My friends got the spicy pork and it was very tasty but a little oily . I used some of the Hawaiian rolls and put the spicy pork on it and made my own korean pulled pork sandwich and it was rather delicious.  My only complaint is not really from me because I am familiar with Korean food but some of my friends were not familiar with Korean food and were kinda lost on what to order. The menu doesn't have any photos of food but has plenty of old photos to simulate a retro yearbook. Menu is more hip and for show than functional. Waitress was friendly and helpful in trying to describe what each item is like. The entrance is like a shop where you can buy clothes, candy and drinks. The restaurant was just a few steps to the back of the shop. Overall I really liked the atmosphere and food. I would definitely return on my next trip to Vegas.

Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Hawaiian Rolls
Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kogi Tacos

WlJnjO26NQcmsQy7pfjuYQ.text: This place has been open for just over two weeks. We went the night before the start of the Consumer Electronics Show, and given the buzz over this place, we expected it to be jammed, but it was only about 2/3 full. Food was all good, and it was nice that Roy Choi (founder) came over and let us get a picture with him. Overall, a good experience, but I can't help but recall we can get K-food that is just as good or better at mom and pop restaurants in the Bay Area, at prices that are much more reasonable. This is priced for tourists on the LV Strip, and also reflects the hip "club-like" interior, so guests are definitely paying the premium for location and hipness.

Tvc3f-O_O4tbPU_670T31g.text: We are not the demographic for the restaurant (In our 60's) but we were staying at The Park, were in the mood for something new and interesting, and after reading the reviews decided to give it a try. Don't know the history and are not familiar with his other restaurants. Like the setup where it looks like you are going to dinner in the back of a bodega. Really interesting dining room, the server was engaged and helped us work through the menu. We started out with the BBQ short ribs, and the eggplant. Both had interesting preparations and were quite good. We asked and they agreed to make us a small pot of the chicken vegetable stew. It was amazing. Could be my favorite dish in any restaurant in years. If you are open to trying something new and different you have to give this a try.

Ij2MzwxZiZk18ClIb8-DMg.text: Great, fast service! They literally treat you like friends. Food is fantastic. We had the short rib tacos and uni fried rice. Cool, unique and eccentric atmosphere.

vYfjXoxWUGPgam4v7L-51g.text: This place was Great!  High energy and very stimulating environment with super service and great food.  Stop in to enjoy a very unique mixture of Korean/ LA Fusion cuisine.  Everything we had was exceptional and very delicious.  The music was a bit loud at 11PM on a Friday night, but Hey---Its VEGAS BABY!  We will definitely return the next time we are in LV.  I'd suggest that you make a reservation, since the place was very active.  I've been to Korea many times and I really liked the food.  The menu was not totally Korean, since they bring a lot of Their LA Food Truck tradition to Vegas.  Overall, a very fun and interesting place with great food.  Give it a try.

dAl5KEM94dG27r2VMK__dw.text: Overall experience with good love the vibe of the place. Serve family style but small portion so order your own you can't share because you won't be full if you do lol  I would go back if I was ever in Vegas and want to grab a bite to eat.

photos.caption: Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States

fdQgk_onpoXOtLiXPSn1XA.text: One big draw of Vegas is its awesome restaurants and top chefs, such as Julian Serrano at Aria and Jaleo by Jose Andres as well as China Poblano at Cosmopolitan, which we dined in multiple times and always enjoy the whole experience afresh every time. Now we would add to this short list a brand new restaurant Best Friend by Roy Choi. We made reservation through MGM app since we stayed in Park MGM (formerly Monte Carlo). Having read Chef Choi's cookbook/autobiography "LA Son" a couple years back, we were eager to taste the flavors of his fusion style. And the dishes did not disappoint. The starters, Kimchi and cucumbers were authentic and pure. Kogi short rib tacos made believers out of us with True LA street flair and tender BBQ meat. Chego pork belly bowl may be our favorite that was a combination of hot sweet sour zesty flavors. Slippery shrimp is kind of popcorn shrimps covered in creamy nutty spicy sauce. Yummy! We ordered A-Frame OG ribs but simply could not finished and had to box the rest. For dessert the fruity milk shaved ice was refreshing, a nice palate cleanser. All in all a very satisfying first visit. Look forward to the next visit very soon :)

photos.caption: Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chego pork belly bowl - our favorite
Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States. A-Frame OG ribs
Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Slippery shrimp

6L08MCGZPHg9O1fy284x3w.text: Wow!!!  We visited from LA a couple weeks ago.  We were familiar with his food from the Koji truck, so we couldnt wait to try it out.  This place is amazing!  We went on the Friday night we were there, and then back again the next night and brought some friends along.  We are planning another trip next weekend-and we cant wait to go back!  The flavors of each dish were on point!  We wanted to keep going but we were all so full.  Great place to share-try everything!  See you soon Best Friend!

BSkbj9mkwdoklSOZEe9UmQ.text: We've eaten from the Kogi truck in L.A. several times and also made a trip to Watts to eat at Locol, so I guess you can say I'm a fan of Chef Choi.  Suffice to say, Best Friend did not disappoint!  We had the Chego Pork Belly Bowl, Charred Octopus, Kogi Tacos, Dumplings, Fries w/Sambal Mayo, Kimchi Fried Rice Arancini and the Sundae For Two.  Fantastic flavors abound!  Chef Choi is not afraid to put a little spicy goodness in his dishes, and I appreciate that SO MUCH.  Friendly service and a very cool decor to be had at Best Friend.  Check it out!

7USC5u00hkQ0mC9K_XdyLQ.text: Super chill place. Went with friends and had a great time. Service was good except for when our waitress forgot a beer. Alcohol was expensive for size cup but it was not lacking liquor. There were 6 of us and our bill was about $330 with liquor included. Food is family style so we each ordered different things and got to try a little of each.

6s3qm_WTNNQ-UkrAiAWZlg.text: I have tried their food in LA couple times. It was amazing food. Made reservation on OpenTable. Show up on time, it's a little difficult to find host, it looks like snack bar/grocery cashier. Check in with host and was told I have to wait 10-15 minutes. Check with host again after 20 minutes, I was told I have to wait another 10-15 minutes. We decide to eat at bar. It doesn't make sense if they can't honor the reservation. The restaurant even report me no show to OpenTable. It really upset me.  The server/bartender really know about their food and drinks. We have octopus, bbq kalbi, slippery shrimp, kimchi fried rice. The food is amazing. Price is a little higher than the Korean restaurant off the Strip, but the flavor, quality, presentation are so good. I'm not big sweet tooth person. But I definitely like the dessert (Bingsu), it's shave ice with milk and dragon fruit.  You definitely should try this restaurant if you like Korean food!!

photos.caption: Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Bingsu
Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Slippery Shrimp

VsL-QsumZr7Y0XfjoJwbAQ.text: Just overall fun restaurant-menu to include all of chef Roy's classics from LA, such as tacos (from Kogi) and Itaewon stew (from POT). Amazing cocktail list which did include many classic drinks. Got to meet chef Roy which was very cool, too. Picked up a couple of Jeff Staple collab shirts on the way out.

photos.caption: Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Forget what this was called. It may have been &#34;the incredible&#34;
Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Itaewon stew was amazing.
Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States. You have to have the tacos.

4AsN-T6uPY3fATYg0bwMUg.text: Ehh, it was ok. Would not go back at these prices. Ordered Kalbi bbq. It was good but I make it at home so nothing special. Uni dynamite rice was good but the portion was exceedingly small. Kids had mixed tempura and dumplings which were nothing special. Wife ordered some type of bourbon peach slushy that was overly sweet and you couldn't even taste the bourbon. It was so weak, I would've had no qualms letting my 10 year old drink it. A complete joke of a cocktail for $18. The music was insanely loud. Couldn't even carry on a conversation in the place. Is this a restaurant or a club?

9oRI3mWbhYoJV_Ee-Qnccg.text: I visited the restaurant on their second week of opening. The restaurant has a prominent Los Angeles theme with various imageries of Los Angeles plastered on their walls. Sadly, other than the theme of the restaurant, the restaurant fails to convey LA's Korean food scene.  Although the restaurant offered a good number of Korean food, I was mainly disappointed by their food quality, or their lack of. We ordered kalbi, braised octopus, and kimchi fried rice. No dish ordered were particularly flavorful or memorable, and the prices were high considering the portion and quality. What made the experience worse was their service. It seemed like they weren't trained well and didn't work in conjunction with the kitchen; our food arrived in random orders that made clear that kitchen had no idea what order dishes were being sent out. For instance, they sent out galbi first (which was a very small portion for $28 and also lacking in meat) without rice or the kimchi rice we ordered. We stared at the galbi for good ten minutes until the rest of the food came out. Two stars.

VlCgeKFAi69r0o8IlmT98g.text: Everything was small portions and expensive, don't know how folks pay for these dishes.... $17 $18 $20ish what happened to $6-7 8-9 wtf but lucky I had comps at Mgm wings tasted like just regular hot wings

photos.caption: Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Korean wings
Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Taco

vzlKYPLg3PU_6LrWVqWXlg.text: Coolest place ever! The fried chicken is out of this world and the kimchi rice is on point. They also have tall boys of Tiger beer which is a classic. Great music, wish they would put their playlist on Spotify!

TqNlFI7NUprbONRZFRMp0A.text: Amazing!!!!!!! The short rib tacos were mind blowing! The spicy pork is to die for. This place is definitely busy so make a reservation if you can or if you are going with a large group. Try to book it a couple of days in advance because the spots fill up quick. This isn't just a restaurant it's an experience. I loved the early 90's theme. But of course the best part is the amazing food! We also had dumplings, the cucumbers with chili paste, spinach, and kimchi. Everything we delicious. The short rib tacos are a necessity! We had the short rib and the spicy pork for the main dishes and both were excellent but the spicy pork was definitely the star. You have to order a side of rice if you want rice with your meal and most of the items on the menu are family style so that you can share with your best friend. Every detail of this restaurant is on point. Also be sure to try the mango dessert. It's an excellent palate cleanser and a perfect way to end dinner.

Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Dumplings
Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Short rib tacos

uJkv7rWPl9BtVLRXWEEU4Q.text: Kogi has lived up to the hype.  The short rib tacos were amazing and so was the Kim Chi fried rice

photos.caption: Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States

IR9fLNYjw06iGjiSckgjeg.text: I had heard about Roy Choi because of his involvement with Jon Favreau on the movie Chef. When I saw that he had a restaurant in Las Vegas I jumped at the opportunity to visit! My girlfriend and I ended up getting the street corn, pork belly, and street tacos. Between the two of us we had plenty of food and even took some home. The wait staff were very knowledgeable and friendly. The best part was after about a week we opened up the pork belly and street corn and it was just as tasty as when we ordered it! I highly recommend it if you are in the area!

vCBvz1WH2aiVGuPW8hfUIw.text: SUCH A GREAT VIBE!!! Music is soo good!! The food is amazing....get the slippery shrimp, black cod stew, uni dynamite rice and the dumplings...service is great too!!

photos.caption: Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Uni Dynamite Rice
Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Slippery Shrimp
Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Dumplings

LWGFHhaKDvZ8zTnMHqHPsg.text: Very urban LA and fun with a touch of Korea, and definitely food for your Seoul. This new gem is literally inside the newly renovated and reinvented PARK MGM, right next to EATALY, conveniently located! It's so cute, it threw me off coming inside. Apparently the receiving area and where your host checks you in for your table is located in a 'convenient store' for chips and snacks and liquor. I had to ask the host, "where is the restaurant side?" Ha! She pointed right through the plastic curtain-doors! It was an experience so fun, we enjoyed taking pictures and trying out their specials. The touch of urban LA slash Korea slash everything diverse and hip and young from the decor to the printed out menus. Let's mention the food btw, served from awesome servers in sweatpants adidas. We tried the fusion tacos of carnitas and steak, also the spicy pork dumplings, and then the Pork Belly Bowl--was just good enough for 3 to share. Did I mention the mouth-watering Hawaiian roles (that I can't probably replicate in my own kitchen)? Leave space for that. --YUM. I can't wait to bring my BEST FRIENDS!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States

T_yy4TrMQ22YOw30-ezjog.text: Had the short rib tacos, elote and kimchi fried rice. The short ribs were very flavorful but then the heat hits you and you can't taste anything else! The kimchi rice was by far my favorite of the things we ordered. I'm definitely going to crave that! So glad we gave this place a try! Fun atmosphere.

SDKfVjZJ1aSjkIetpizjLg.text: I ate here for my birthday during their soft opening and I have a few things that I want to remark on: 1st- the front of the restaurant looks like a bodega when you walk in. You can order appetizers from the bar in the front resting area and the small candies and things at the register. The entryway gave no indication of how dope the actual restaurant is. 2nd- when seated in the actual restaurant it was a very beautiful and comfortable setting. The opening ceilings was covered nicely with huge hanging plants and the mural walls were a very nice focal point. 3rd- the food!!!! I splurged on my birthday so it was pretty pricey but it was well worth it (take a look at the photo of my tomahawk steak). The menu was a cool Korean- west coast fusion. The Korean items on the menu such as the hotpot were served in large pot where a group of 4 could share comfortably. The menu was so diverse that I truly believe there was something for everyone. My boyfriend ordered the half-rack of lamb and those were just as delicious as my steak. 4th- the drinks were so damn good! That's really I can say about it.  My only semi-negative remark would be that the tables are so small and can't really fit all of the food that comes out (if you're fatty and order six things like I did). The food came out faster than I could consume but that's definitely not a bad thing!!

m9eJovrdAnS_tnDXU8iPXw.text: Me and my family had a really good time here really nice environment excellent service and good food where definitely gonna eat here again

7-lxR1hW7xXhEd6IT54Oxw.text: They had only been opened for about 12 days when my party of five went for dinner. It was vinyl Thursday night. I loved the atmosphere and the food was finger licking. The waiter was funny and thorough at explaining the menu to our table. The price was a bit expensive for the size of food you get.  We had a great time and would definitely go back when we are in Vegas.

Kw9ZfaZ7hAKJ9e34nVx2ug.text: Super cool theme and interior design. Love the storefront entrance and the retro, downscale looking sign/graphics. We had reservations early as we had show tix for later. Ordered two of the prix fixe menu for $55 each and meant to order Salmon Teriyaki for our sons, but got the Salmon Enchilada instead. It wasn't really an enchilada, but grilled salmon w/ enchilada sauce, pickled veg, and salsa verde. That was only okay, but the fish was perfectly cooked, medium inside. The food came out surprisingly quickly. First was the slippery shrimp which was awesome. Crispy, with a bit of creamy spice. Also got the street corn, limey and cheesy, delish also. The eggplant schnitzel was good, too, but served w/ a mustard sauce, which is not my favorite condiment. Crispy on the outside, melty on the inside. The Kogi shortrib tacos were actually not my fave, just kind of meh for me. Also had the pork belly rice bowl, very good. The roasted carrots, cannot remember their actual name, were fine. Cannot remember what other items were on the menu, but dessert was a date cake w/ caramel ice cream and whipped cream, also excellent. Loved the school binder menu w/ retro photos, that brought me back to my own youth (Sadie Hawkins dance photos!!).   Oh, and complimentary, hot, buttery Hawaiian rolls to start. YUM!   My only criticism, which another Yelper also mentioned, is that the busboy asked us to eat/remove one of the buns off of the plate so he could remove it. WHAT? Who does that? That along with the dishes arriving in extreme rapid succession, two-three at a time, made the meal feel very rushed and frenetic. Made it hard to savor the meal -- I'm not expecting pacing like a 5-star French restaurant, but still. Like, are they trying to get us to leave sooner and have the table available for someone else? That just felt weird... but I really didn't like being rushed to eat our rolls...   Anyhoo, very creative, great consistency of the food quality, love the theme (from interior design, including artwork, to staff uniforms, menu appearance, etc). Thumbs up!

UW2_jwQNDkIHNqCt861veg.text: Restaurant has a very cool look with the convenience/liquor store front and the LA styled garden behind closed doors for the actual restaurant. There was even a DJ in house!  All the food our table tried was excellent. This included the wings (which are spicer than your normal wings but it wasn't off putting at all), and the Big E from the OC for appetizers and I had the Kalbi beef ribs for my main course.  We had a bit of a wait for the Kalbi for some reason it came out 20-30 mins later than the rest of the entrees the table ordered. They made up for this with a free order of the shrimp appetizer (which was also good!).

v46FM8AgJwiK9FH0oAXs9w.text: Love the vibe and atmosphere of the restaurant. Makes me think of LA and I'm from LA. The food was good. Especially the uni dynamite rice. Loved their drinks as well and was surprised to see that they had a Jameson Ginger slushie. It is pricey for the type of food but it's also Vegas, so expected. Service was good.

Hybtm4_qEu7YDaJneuNAIw.text: I've been a fan of zRoy for many years and looked forward to his LA style Korean/ Hispanic mix here in town. The ambience is definitely styled to give you a hip LA feeling and I think it largely succeeds. Tried the short rib tacos, seafood noodles, tempura plate and bonachon plate. Very impressed with the bonachon and tempura and liked tg3 seafood noodles. Somewhat disappointed by short rib tacos, resulting in a lowering of my score. The issues I found with the tacos were a bit of gristle in the meat and the quality of the tortillas. I believe an important part of the taco is the tortilla and Roy's fell short. I would return because there's many other items I would try.

f5ErwnkiY3U9gfZ1PiXosg.text: Came in for my wife's birthday dinner.  Asked do a corner table so she could watch the kitchen.  We were denied after being told it was for party of four.  Then watched them seat two guys. What gives?!  Very good bancha sampler, bbq vegetables and Korean dumplings.  Very disappointed that the carnitas tacos no longer on menu. Pricey for what you get, but tasty.

photos.caption: Photo of Best Friend by Roy Choi - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Two guys that got the end &#34;table for four&#34;

7YnwqXLqNNyBYSyf-uIDPA.text: genuinely authentic place. Not following the latest trend, this restaurant is themed by its own sense of style. Great old school hip hop plays while staff, who clearly enjoy their job, provide exceptional service. We only had a few drinks and two appetizers, but those tacos and dumplings were both incredible.  I wish there were more places like this...

pfhRXZeTaqJMzufv6ZjnXw.text: I was in Vegas for a bachelorette party, and we decided to have dinner at Best Friend. We did the pre fixe menu for $100 each.   Sorry, but our group did not enjoy our experience for the following reasons.   1) Service: I will say that the initial courses came quickly, however at the end we waited more than 45 minutes for our dessert to come. Server was hard to track. 2) Food: all the food was mediocre. I am also not sure why they would serve all the carb heavy entrees first(bread rolls, fried rice, tacos) then serve the protein dishes last (teriyaki chicken, bulgolgi, steak). We ended up with sooo much protein leftovers.  3) Dessert Situation: IN ADDITION to the dessert arriving 45 minutes later finishing our main course (and tracking down our server more than 3 times for an update), we didn't get everything we paid for!! We had a large party, split into two long tables. As each course came out, 5 plates of each dish would be served, 3 on one table(of 13 girls), and 2 on the other table(of 8 girls). That worked well because that meant around 4 people would share each plate. EXCEPT for one of the desserts, the pink (strawberry?) dessert. 3 plates arrived on larger table, and only 1 on the other. I happened to be at the table where there was only one and my end of the table didn't have it. When I tracked down the waiter again to question if another one was coming, he told me no and that we had to share it. WHAT??? You want me to share one small dessert with 7 other people? Luckily I did snag a bite and realized pretty quickly that I wouldn't want it anyway. But, it's still principle to get what you paid for!   Anyway, I don't plan to be back.

Ysq8nxmOytIgREBUT5Qxnw.text: Such a good place to check out in Vegas. I strongly recommend the Uni FRIED rice and the Mango Dulce de Leche dessert!

7d-eNpNTIh-YIaRitvj-cQ.text: This place is so good. The ambience of the restaurant is so cute and very chill. I found out it opened recently so we made dinner reservations and my expectations were definitely met.   We ordered the Kogi Short Rib Tacos and Korean Wings. Both of the dishes were pretty good and the korean wings was different than the normal yangnyum chicken I normally order. It seemed like the sauce was mainly gochujang but the dish wasn't bad.   The reason why I gave this place five stars was because of the dessert. The food was decent but the dessert blew my mind. We ordered the Mango Budino and the Bingsu. I've had many different bingsu over the years but I've never tried it like how best friend made their dish.   This place is definitely worth trying if you are ever in Vegas. I had a really enjoyable experience!!

lnxKFLFIHCQ7699oRaGTOw.text: This one is going to sting for a long time. It will be seared like a hot poker in my memory among bad experiences. The difficulty to explain is how food can be rendered "ok to serve" when it reflects Chef Roy Choi in such terrible light. I am certain, if he was there this evening, kitchen staff would not have been allowed.  To say we were excited for our pilgrimage to Best Friend, would be an understatement. It was to be an event for us. Having no perceived ideas other than what is known about Chef Roy Choi, an LA legend, we prepared gleefully and dare I admit and announce, fasted, to arrive ravenous. It became a comedy gone awry. A total waste of a waist.   The restaurant has great soul. An upbeat vibe with a makeshift humongous pantry upon entering, a live DJ playing music and a Hostess cubicle reminiscent of Charlie Brown's Lucy with her lemonade stand.  Our reservations of four announced and in we go! To quote Elvis (hey this is Vegas!) "Thats when your heartaches begin."   I must make mention here that we are from a Korean family, therefore, while not experts on all foods, we are pretty well versed on these type of dishes Chef Roy Choi is famous for.  Our server Miss Stacey couldn't have been nicer. Eric along with Wayne(sic?) were attentive and on cue throughout the evening. We contemplated whether to order their prix fix (there are 2 choices) or go with several dishes, try, and then order the prix fix. We were greedy and super hungry. Here is the rundown/lowdown: Bottle of wine- very reasonably priced and delicious 2 mixed drinks one which arrived in a red Solo cup! Awesome!  *3 ban chan plates: Kimchi, Cucumbers, and Brussel sprouts. Most likely the hit of the evening. Not too fermented which is ok for me. Slightly more on the vinegary side with a crisp fresh appeal.  *Dumplings: So tender we had trouble picking them up as the wonton skin fell apart.(please see photo) *Carnitas tacos: Dry till it hurt to chew. Would you believe the lime was non-juicy as well? Squeezed it till the spray came from the peel.  *Short Rib tacos: Also dry. Not sure if the meat sat too long in the kitchen. Very disappointing.   *Korean Chicken Wings: No way! How can these be lacking? Lacked flavor(non-marinated?) and the legs were dry. Further disappointment.  *Itaewon stew: better known as "Army Stew" with what is suppose to be a fluid liquid and variety of noodles, spam, wieners, and veggies. Except, this  broth was thick as molasses. Please see photo of the upper pan where the liquid was reduced to paste. If it was heated on the stovetop, they left it too long. If it was in the oven, they left it too long. All items in the stew were overcooked and falling apart in your mouth. And the flavoring? A sodium brine. (Please see photos) To tell you we had leftovers and left them, is a crime. But we did, as we left behind anything not touched on pans and serving plates. Chef Roy Choi, this cannot be you. More than anything, it saddens me to think the crew in the kitchen was not looking out for your best interest. Photos tell the tale and I'm hoping you'll paddle their tails.   All is only my opinion and as always, thanks for reading =)

9bI-cQnqHVPGg5075TQjpQ.text: Food is very good but overpriced. Space is loud and super laid back so weird vibe coming from Park. This space is LA through and through. Laid back waiters, takes time to take your order, inconsistent kitchen timing, too spendy, but great food. We ordered a la carte but a bit of everything; it all came out way too quick so table was packed. Chicken wings were very poor but other than that all bbq and main dishes were great. Tacos excelled and lived up and ban chan was good, though should've been complimentary not $16 which is a complete ripoff. Chicken was standout bbq for me as was the crispy rice with uni which though not Korean really blew me away. Desert game was on with the cheesecake stealing the show and bingsu just a necessity for Korean dinner. Slushees affordable for drinks and super boozy. Total rice is very affordable with expected $70 a person to get super full and a few drinks. I'd recommend the prix fixe which is $50-$65 if you're a small group to get a fee for the restaurant - has all the best ofs and comes out quick to experience Vegas more. Music is loud but music is good and 90s rap base rap; if you're into that, you'll be good. Definitely more authentic spots in the city for social (Soyo) or bbq (Hobak), but for the strip, I'm glad they finally have a quality high end Korea that is at least respectable and hip.

uJ3owQT1FE7i_5vt-oV-_g.text: The atmosphere was awesome, loved the music, the decor was awesome. Food was so good! I had the AYCE that they have on monday. I had a plate of the kalbi, the prime ribeye, and the shrimp. All of them were amazing but I'd have to say the Kalbi was my ultimate favorite.

N5wKdHxr98GjJD3FnO1_9w.text: Disappointed.... Went there with high expectations but left pretty sad....  Idk if its bc i am an angeleno or what but...this isnt (can you feel my disappointment)   First of all...as we walked in the hostess had a condescending attitude...a bit cocky and a bit rude   We sat and decided on our food but found some items on the menu is no longer available...please print new menus....didnt look like it costed much to make the menus anyhow...   Then we ordered:   E.O.C Uni Dynamite Rice  Slippery Shrimp Elotes Kogi Rib Taco  Elotes: mexican style corn  Was the only thing we thought was okay...  The ingredients seems fresh but execution was a fail....  Couldnt find any korean flavors....too much butter and oil in everything... Walked out and saw Eatly and wish we'd gone there instead   We did not have any issue with Service hence 2 stars instead of 1

Bfqmiz4HGSrtx2o3iXd9qw.text: One of my favorite restaurants in Vegas! The food and cocktails are amazing. I have been several times now, and a few of my favorites are the kimchi fired rice, the short rib tacos, the lamb, and definitely the sundae (it's in a bathtub!) or date cake for dessert. One of the amazing chefs, River, made sure everything was delicious, and we couldn't have been more satisfied.  The ambiance/aesthetic of the whole restaurant is great with the front area and the restaurant in the back. They also have a live DJ sometimes! All of the staff is amazing as well (shout out to our wonderful server Gabriel!). We will definitely continue to frequent this great spot.

vKidsH1UDEPGF9vnNL6KCA.text: We just finished dinner and I feel so strongly about how incredible this place is that I'm writing this review while my mom is signing the receipt for the bill. Just amazing Korean and Mexican food. The service was very thoughtful. My mom was being extremely difficult and they handled it with kindness and consideration. The manager came over twice to ask what she could do for my mom. A real class act. I can't recommend this place enough.

80OHXbS8U2oKnzatg_BVfQ.text: The ambiance was spot on with the DJ and the track pants, but you go back for the food. Everything we had was delicious. The spicy pork was the dish I'd order again and again.

PHuFrTkhg628mkZtKVjrew.text: This was on our bucket list as we are big fans of Roy Choi & love his cookbook too!   Everyone was super friendly!  We had Christina who really knew the menu and could help make the right choices.  Started out with the fries, they had just the right crunch and the ramen seasoning on top was so tasty!  The Korean bbq beef was  marinated for 3 days it came on a bed of onions. Every bite made you salivate for more!  We also added more carbs to our order- cause who cares we're in Vegas!  The Kimchee fried rice was cooked to perfection and each bite was delicious!  We topped off with a special desert "Date night"  it added just the right touch .. not to sweet.. just oh, so good.    Thank you For making this such a fun experience!  We also loved the decor and seating.  Can't wait to make this a return visit! Tip- Ask to sit in the lounge chairs for dinner so comfy!

lA8z1hkf7Z2-AzzkLft3Qw.text: Love me some Roy Choi and was happy to see he opened up BF in Vegas! A super fun vibe from the soda shop storefront bar to the spacious inside of the restaurant, and the laid back waiters in track suits.   The menu is pretty great here - seriously something for everyone. Don't skip the cocktails either - super creative and delicious. As for the food itself, we loved everything we ordered. Yes - it's not your typical Korean BBQ place as it's a smidge pricier BUT it is authentic modern Korean flavors. We liked everything we tried - the galbi, the dumplings, the pork adobo fried rice and a few other things.   Highly recommend a visit if you're looking for some good Korean with an LA twist in LV.

QPvo-iUtvDyl_PmQJ6pFIA.text: Cool LA 90s vibe with Vegas prices.  Got a chuckle from the yearbook style menu.  The food?  Well, I'd say it's the same level as any Korean Restaurant.  The Kimchi Fried Rice has Crispy Rice mixed in which was a nice surprise but it was a bit too salty.  Ban Chans we're good but again it's not any better than your typical Korean BBQ restaurant.  My final thoughts....over rated and over priced.  I'll stick to Roy's Kogi Trucks.

kf3X-h_i6qk2FIZt0ZprRA.text: This was an absolutely amazing experience! From the moment you walk in thinking, "this can't be it!" Then you're taking away by the scene. Our server was perfect, selecting the signature dishes for us. Absolutely mouth watering delicious each plate, the spicy shrimp, the fried chicken, oh the steak and how can I forget the desert. By the way, best fried rice I've ever had!! I loved the menus, like 8th grade folders for school!! So amazing thanks again to a dear friend for inviting us.
